March 26th, 1914.

Madam -

Referring to my communication of the 10th instant in reference to the Caugimawaga schools, Mr. MacKenzie of this Department will call upon you on Saturday to discuss the matter.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. Sister Melanie,
Superior General,
Sisters of Ste. Anne,
Mount Ste. Anne,
Lachine, Que.
April 4th, 1914.

Madam -

Mr. MacKenzie has reported to me the result of his interviews with yourself and your staff at Lachine on the 28th and 29th ultimo.

I regret very much that your Order does not see its way to take the control of both the boys' and the girls' school on the Caughmasaga Reserve. I am not disposed, however, to make any differentiation between the boys and the girls and if any change is to be made I would like both of these institutions to be included.

However, I quite appreciate the difficulties that lie in the way from your point of view and in thus concluding our negotiations I wish to express my appreciation of your kindness and courtesy in giving the matter careful consideration.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Rev. Sister Melanie,
Superior General,
Sisters of Ste. Anne,
Mount Ste. Anne,
Lachine, Que.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Referring to your letter of the 21st ultimo and my reply thereto of the 23rd of that month, Mr. Martin Benson has returned to headquarters and I am now prepared to state that the boys' and girls' schools on the Caughnawaga reserve will be handed over to the charge of the Sisters on the re-opening of the schools on January 5th, 1915.

The salaries allowed will be $500.00 for the Principal, $400.00 for the first assistant, and $300.00 for the second assistant, it being understood that all are to be the holders of proper professional qualifications.

Mr. Benson states that, owing to the scarcity of teachers in your Order, you wish to retain the services of the Misses Burke, and to this the Department will agree provided the retention is temporary and their place will be taken by qualified teachers of the Order as soon as it is possible for you to obtain

Rev. Sister Marie Melanie,
Mount Saint Anne,
Lachine, Que.
December 19th, 1914.

Dear Sir,

This letter is to confirm arrangements made with you by Mr. MacKenzie in connection with the Sisters' dwelling in the village.

You should remove the furniture not required by the Sisters, and then engage some women to clean the rooms; you may also have the floors painted.

In connection with the closet it is proposed to erect on the balcony, this should be constructed of studding and double boarded with two plies of heavy felt paper. If there is glass in the door it will not be necessary to provide a window in the closet. This should be carefully arranged so that it can be kept warm if possible.

The furnishings for the building will arrive from Montreal on Monday, December 28th, and the house should be ready before that date.

Yours very truly,

F. McD. Jacobs, Esq.,
Mayor,
Caughnawaga, Que.

Deputy Superintendent General.
December 19th, 1914.

Sir,

When Mr. MacKenzie of this Department was in Caughnawaga on Thursday, he authorized Mr. Jacobs to have certain work done in connection with the Sisters' residence. Mr. Jacobs is acting under power of attorney for the owner of the building. Mr. MacKenzie also authorized Mr. Daillebout to furnish six tons of coal; the accounts for this work and material will be forwarded through your office.

Before the Sisters take charge of the boys' school after the Christmas holidays, you will be good enough to arrange to have the teachers' desks and chairs varnished, and also to have the pupils' desks on the second storey repaired where necessary.

An arrangement was also entered into whereby Mr. Jacobs is to receive 25¢ a trip for driving the Sisters to and from the boys' school in inclement

J. M. Brosseau, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Constant, Que.
weather.

The Department will pay during the winter months for a care-taker at the Sisters' dwelling, whose duties will be to attend the fires, shovel the snow, bring water, etc., and will allow for this service, $10.00 per month. Mr. Frank Rice the present care-taker at the boys' school will undertake this work and you may make the necessary arrangements with him.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.
December 21st, 1914.

Dear Mr. Colquhoun,

I should esteem it a favour if you would be good enough to have forwarded to Sister Mary Edward, Ste. Anne's Convent, Lachine, Que., a copy of the school regulations of your Department, and also the curriculum of studies for public schools in the Province of Ontario.

This Sister has been appointed supervisor of our schools in the village of Caughnawaga, and wishes to follow the Ontario curriculum.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

A. H. U. Colquhoun, Esq., B.A., LL.D.,
Deputy Minister of Education,
Toronto, Ont.
Esteemed Sir,

I trust you will not consider me impertinent if I address you today with regard to the plan which you so kindly allowed the Caughnawaga schools in the past, for the purchase of premiums usually awarded the children at the closing exercises. The children have worked in view of these rewards and shall be disappointed if deprived of them.
I should feel very grateful if a grant of $60.00 was given for both schools - $15.00 each. This great favor added to the many acts of kindness and generosity towards us during the short time we have been under the Department shall be greatly appreciated by the Sisters. We have certainly worked hard since we have come to Cathcartwaga. Our task is a most arduous one. However, we feel that we may always rely upon your kind encouragement.

I remain,

Most esteemed Sir,

With the highest consideration,

[Signature]

Ottawa, 20th December, 1897.

Sir,

I transmit herewith an account received from "The Star" of Montreal, for advertising for a teacher of the Caughnawaga Indian School, and I beg to draw your attention to the note on the account to the effect that the bill was sent to you without your taking any notice of the same. Ottawa, June 11, 1915.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo asking for a grant for prizes for the pupils of the Caughnawaga Boys' and Girls' Schools.

In reply I beg to say that the pupils of these two schools were allowed prizes at Christmas and it is customary to only make a grant for prizes once in each school year. However, this year an exception will be made in the case of the Boys' and Girls' Schools and you may expend the sum of $15.00 in the purchase of prizes for the pupils of each of these schools. Detailed accounts for these prizes, in duplicate, should be sent to Mr. Agent Brosseau, who will be instructed to certify them and forward them to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

T. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Sister M. Edward,
Principal,
Caughnawaga R.C. Schools,
Caughnawaga, Que.
Ottawa, February 9, 1916.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that it has been decided to grant Sister Mary Edward, Principal of the Boys' and Girls' schools on the Caughnawaga Reserve, a salary at the rate of $500.00 a year from the first of January last. Sister Edward has not previously been paid any salary for her services as supervising principal of these schools and it is considered in the interests of the work and in justice to Sister Edward that she be granted the above salary and she has been so informed.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. M. Brosseau, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Constant, Que.
Caughnawaga Feb. 12, 1916.

Hon. D.C. Scott,
Ottawa.

Most esteemed Sir:

Your exceedingly kind favor of the 8th inst. brought joy to our little Community. My first act after reading it was to send copies of it to the Archbishop of Montreal and to our Mother General who are both deeply interested in the welfare of our work in Caughnawaga. I hope to return your good Sir, Scott, my heartfelt thanks for the sympathetic attention with which you so kindly honored my humble request. The salary of $500.00 is most gratefully accepted and the enrolment of the staff is considered very satisfactory.

It is truly kind of you, esteemed Sir,

[Signature]

Caughranaga, June 12, 1872

J. D. Sir James, Esq.,
Ottawa.

Respected Sir,

Your very kind favor of the 6th inst. is received. I beg to return sincere thanks for your goodness in granting our children rewards at the Closing exercises.

With the highest consideration,

Yours most respectfully,

H. M. Edward, Principal

Caughranaga School.
Caughrinage, June 26, 1916.

J. E. Lee, Esq.,
Ottawa

Most esteemed Sir,

I beg leave to apologize for having taken action in asking for children to be sent home from Spanish Industrial School. I had been misinformed regarding my duty in such case.

I have mailed the quarterly Return to the Agent for me to close on June during the month of July. We shall all spend the month of July in Cashin. I would therefore take it as a great favor if you will kindly address
for the privilege for the 10th meet.

Thanking you esteemed Sir,

for your kind favor

I remain,

With the highest consideration,

S. M. Edward, Principal
them. There will be no objection to their remaining until the end of the June term, 1915, and their salaries will be continued by the Department at the present rate. Under this arrangement the Order will be required to provide for January a Principal for the girls' school and a staff of three for the boys' school.

It is desired to take up at once the question of the furnishings for the building to be used temporarily for your accommodation, and I would ask you to be good enough to have your representatives meet Mr. MacKenzie of this Department in the girls' school, Caughnawaga, on Wednesday, December 16th, at 10 A.M.; the building can then be visited and a decision as to equipment reached and the purchase thereof made in Montreal at once.

I have every confidence that the placing of these schools in charge of the Sisters of Saint Anne will have good results and that at no distant date the Caughnawaga schools will rank among the best of the Indian schools in our country.

Kindly advise me by return mail if this arrangement as to Mr. MacKenzie's visit will be satisfactory.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) J.S. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.
Dear Mr. Ethier,

Not knowing whom to address in the Department, I send you this information; perhaps you could do something.

Peter Delisle is beginning his business again! Yesterday, at the close of high mass, he made an incendiary speech and announced a great meeting that is to take place this evening, Monday, to consider means that could be taken to expel Mr. Popart and to prevent the building of the convent. Philis real disorder! How is it that this man is allowed thus to raise an agitation, to trouble the village, to harangue against the decisions of the Department, against established order, against this and against that? With ignorant and credulous people such as ours...
a fanatic such as he can turn anything upside down. Could not the Department strictly prohibit these meetings called solely to create disorder and unwholesome agitation? I know well that he will not succeed in doing what he desires, but that does not alter the fact that he is doing much evil, and say that he ought to be arrested.

Some twenty-five years ago, in somewhat similar circumstances, the Department strictly forbade these disorderly meetings. This was done for the great good of all.

I do not dare to complain too much to the Department, because there reason to believe that there are traitors close by who communicate to Peter Delisle all the information that I can send. In some cases he seems to have been informed.
Certain things before even the Agent.

I hope that the papers for the exchange of land have reached Ottawa. The absence of the archbishop delayed the sending of them.

Best regards to yourself and Mrs. Chêne.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

D. C. Scott, Esq.,
Ottawa

Most esteemed Sir,

Although I have written lengthily to Mr. MacKenzie to reach you, I feel that I am yet very justified in doing so. I feel very sorry to leave the School and particularly to whom my mother has been up by one who is unqualified for it. Mr. Stagg is the only person to settle the matter, and he can do it. Please do not mention that it was I who spoke of my successor. Consider it necessary kind Mr. Scott, indeed I do think it just to inform you of the truth.
for you have been just and kind to me. And I have taken occasion to express my gratitude to you, with my regret to leave my work in Langhamaga undone. As you are aware, Dr. Magpie's residence is on the Captain Murray. Presenting yourself and Mrs. Scott my best regards.

I remain,

With the highest consideration,
Esteemed Mr. Scott,
Your truly devoted servant,
Sr. Mary Edward.

If you insist upon my returning to Langhamaga, I shall come back. The Delegate will be here Saturday. I am late.
Extenent Mr. Scott

I beg to apologize for this abrupt and badly written letter. I am very busy preparing to leave.

Yours respectfully,

Lt. Col. Edward.

August 3rd, 1916.

Dear Madam -

I have a note from Sister Mary Edward, Principal of the Caughnawaga Indian Schools, bidding farewell to the work there and informing me that she is being transferred to another field of usefulness.

As you are aware Sister Mary Edward has been in charge of these schools since the change of management in January 1915, and during the time that has elapsed she has apparently been most successful in handling the situation, which called for the exercise of a great deal of ability and tact.

As you are no doubt aware there has been certain opposition to the policy of the Department and you will agree that it is hardly prudent to change the administrative head at the present before the system has been firmly established. Under all these circumstances I would ask for further consideration in a matter of such importance, which might well be the subject of joint deliberation by yourself and the Department.

Rev. Mother Melanie,
Superior General Sisters of Ste. Anne.
Lachine, Que.
I had the pleasure of visiting the Caughnawaga schools a couple of months ago and I was very much pleased to see the effect of the efforts of the Principal and her assistants in their work among the Indian children of this village, a work which could not be carried on successfully were it not for the cooperation and devotedness of those engaged in it, inspired by your generous supervision.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.
Mont-Sainte-Anne
Lachine, Aug. 8, 1916.

Honorable Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General,
Ottawa.

Honorable Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge your esteemed favor of the 3rd inst. Had I received it a few days earlier, I would have been able to consider your request, but already I had appointed another principal to the Caughnawaga Indian School.

I duly appreciate your words of praise in behalf of Sister M. Edward's ability in handling the education of these schools, but I have every reason to believe that the new principal, Sister M. Joseph Edward of English nationality, is fully qualified to continue the work so well begun by her predecessor. Again the
assistance are the same so I hope that before long you will be able to judge for yourself that the change in the administrative head was in no way detrimental to the system so recently established in these schools.

Yours most respectfully,

[Signature]

St. Constant, Nov. 14, 1916

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

Herewith I send my report of the four Caughnawaga schools for the month of October, 1916. During this month I have not been able to visit the Bush school on account of an excess of work at my office. I may remark to the Department that the furnace in the boys' school is not giving satisfaction; the upper story is not sufficiently heated. I have carefully examined the said furnace, and I have not been able to find out what is defective. When the severe cold comes, this furnace does not send out heat to all the apartments. I ask for authority to get a man of experience to come and put things right.

Yours, &c.,
J.M. Brosseau,
Agent.
Caughnawaga, Mai 8, 1917.

Dear SIR:

I would wish to obtain your interpretation of the law obliging children to attend school till their fifteenth year. Several of our boys of the fifth and sixth forms only fourteen years old work in Dominion Bridge.

On applying to the Indian Agent to compel them to return, he replied that he could not force them to do so, and have them lose their positions for a few weeks only.

Were we to accept such reasoning, the class would soon empty, for when one has taken this liberty the others quickly imitate the example. Is the law to be interpreted at will? If so, why need we hold so much to their daily attendance, if they are free to work when they please? That they leave at fifteen, it is just, but when they have two or three months more to remain before being of age to work, I consider it leniency on the Agent's part not to oblige them to finish the term.

Should they not remain till they are fifteen? Personal experience has taught us that the parents do not resist when the law is placed before them. A little help from the Agent and the truant officer would soon settle this difficulty.

Secondly—Are parents free to withdraw their children at anytime to accompany them on their trips abroad to sell bead-work? This is another great disturbance.

Kindly inform me of the course to be
taken concerning these questions. The Agent would be pleased to know how the law of compulsory education should be interpreted.

Trusting to receive a satisfactory reply,

Respectfully Yours,

[Signature]

Mr. D.C. Scott,
Deputy Sup. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa,
Ont.

Dear Madam -

Mr. MacKenzie informs me that the two Caughnawaga schools were kept in session during the Easter holidays and that on that account you asked to be allowed to close a little earlier this term.

I have pleasure in granting your request and the schools may close a week earlier than usual, namely, the 22nd June.

Caughnawaga Indian Schools,

May 30th, 1917.

Dear Madam -

I beg to refer to your letter of the 5th instant, in reference to compulsory attendance of Indian children at the day schools of Caughnawaga.

Mr. MacKenzie informs me on his recent visit that he discussed this matter with you and that he indicated to you that the Department did not desire to make a rigid enforcement of the regulations. He further tells me that a number of delinquents have returned to school; this I am glad to know. I do not like to have to resort to compulsion unless forced to. I will, however, expect our truant officer to render you every assistance in your work.

Yours very truly,

Rev. Sister M. Joseph Edward,
Principal,
Caughnawaga Indian Schools,
Caughnawaga, Que.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Mr. D.J. McLean,
Assistant Deputy Secretary,

Dear Sir,

I take the liberty of writing to you today, as I learned from looking over the files of the Department of Indian Affairs that correspondence relating to financial matters was addressed to you. Not being familiar with the workings of the Department, nor how the business is subdivided, you will kindly overlook any mistake my inexperience may have me to make.

With a view to improving the conditions in both the Reserve Schools under my direction, and thereby ensuring better results in school-work and discipline, I went over the ground very minutely with your Agent, Mr. Brosseau, pointing out to him that which in my estimation is a serious drawback to the progress of the School. Mr. Brosseau advised me to inform the Department of existing conditions and he was of the opinion that the Officials would be glad to have any suggestion on the matter which might prove helpful.

1. A number of the older desks in the class-rooms are giving away, the castings are broken and it is impossible to have them repaired.

2. The number of hooks in the dressing-rooms is insufficient for the number of pupils, more than half the original number have been broken and nails substituted. The result is that the clothing falls on the floor, and you can easily see the consequences.

3. The Reading Charts are very much worn, and the number is insufficient to meet the needs of the children.
4. The problem of teaching Indian Children to read is extremely difficult because they do not understand the English language. Nothing can be said to interest them, to arouse their attention. It is but a dry repetition of sounds, words and letters. We can appeal to the eye and ear only, the mind we cannot reach.

5. Blackboards in the Girls' School is inadequate. A board about four feet long and two wide is available for fifty-five tots learning to read and write. Can you imagine the success forthcoming?

6. The desks in two classes of the Girls' School are not fastened to the floor, because they have to be removed so often during the year. (These classes are in the assembly room) There is no possibility of keeping ink in these desks, and teaching writing under such difficulties is not an easy task.

I venture to suggest the following for your kind consideration.

1. That the Department fit up the First class in the Boys' School with 30 new single desks, thus allowing us to use the 20 double desks there now to replace those which are broken in the other class-rooms and which have to be cast aside.

2. That one gross of good strong hooks be shipped to the school, and fastened in the ward-robés, with that number on hand we will be able to replace the broken ones according to the needs.

3. That one good set of illustrated Reading Charts be placed in the Receiving Room of each school.

4. That an allowance of a few dollars be made to enable the Principal to purchase a variety of objects to present to the children that they may more easily learn their names. Introduce a "See and Say" method. During this month the children have learned Fifty name words, and it is surprising to see
the interest they show in the work. I would like to see how much we do by trying this method. Five hundred words in the first year is what I hope to realize.

5. That sufficient blackboards be placed in Room No. 4 of Girls' School

6. That the desks be screwed to narrow strips of hard wood. It would hold the castings and give more stability to the desk, besides they could be removed at will.

These are, Dear Sir, a few of the most pressing needs of the School. If you choose to remedy all of them, or even any of them you will be greatly helping the cause of education on this Reserve.

I noticed that $25.00 a year was allowed in the past for supplying material for the sewing classes in the Girls' School, and on May 7th 1915 a letter from you to the Principal, Sister Mary Edward, granted an allowance of $25.00 yearly for the scrubbing and washing of the towels in the Girls' School. Please inform me if these conditions still exist; and if the same amount will be allowed this school year.

As we will soon be moving into more roomy and comfortable quarters, and as much of the furniture in this house belongs to the proprietor, we will have to apply to the Department for what will be needed. I have thought of making out an itemized list of what will be required, giving size of rooms, windows, doors etc. Would this in any way help? It might place you in a position to know how much to allow. I will exercise the strictest economy, and ask for only those things which are indispensable.

Trusting that my demands will not opportune you,

I am, Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 10th instant, with respect to the closing of the schools of Caughnawaga on account of the epidemic of Spanish Grippe, which is prevalent in the village, I have to inform you that on the 7th instant Dr. Patton came to my office and informed me of the epidemic. There were under his care forty-five cases in the village. He told me further that he had been health officer for the reserve for thirty years and that it was his intention to have the schools close until the epidemic was under control.

I told him to wait until I had satisfied myself of the gravity of the epidemic before ordering the closing of the schools. I then had an interview with the Sister Superior, who told me that she had not yet found any cases among the pupils. On the 9th instant the same doctor reported to me that he had upwards of seventy-five cases under his care. The principal of the school told me that several pupils were away on account of illness of which she did not know the nature.

I then had an interview with the Rev. Father Gras, who seemed perfectly well informed of the situation, and we decided to close the schools immediately and to inform the Department of it for approval, and not to re-open them until the epidemic was under control. At the time of my last visit there had been no deaths, but the cases were becoming more and more numerous. Memorandum.

Mr. Scott:

In pursuance of your instructions I met Mr. Inspector Gilman at Caughnawaga on Friday the 28th instant and accompanied him in an inspection of all the class-rooms in the Boys' and Girls' Schools on the Caughnawaga Reserve. I was greatly pleased with the results that they have achieved since my last visit to these schools, shortly after the installation of the Sisters. The school-rooms were bright, clean and cheery, and the class-room work was highly satisfactory. Mr. Gilman, the Public School Inspector, stated that the work compared favourably with that done in the best schools in his Inspectorate. The attendance in each of the rooms was large and an examination of the register showed that since the opening of spring it has been very regular.

The crowding in the Junior class-room of the Girls' School is very noticeable and the Department will have to consider means of relieving the situation, but this is a matter that can be dealt with at a later date.

I made special enquiries regarding the establishment of a continuation class and I am convinced not only that such action would be beneficial to the children of the village but is almost a necessity. There are at the present time in the Boys' class-room five boys who will complete their studies in so far as the ordinary course is concerned at the summer holidays. There are none in the girls' school at the present time but there are prospective students for another year. The object of the continuation class would be to give further instruction in English and a general commercial course, including bookkeeping, typewriting and stenography. Mr. Gilman also suggests instruction in French, which is very essential to young men or women entering commercial life in the city of
Montreal or other cities in the Province of Quebec. The establishment of such a course would to a great extent relieve the Department of the obligation at present existing of defraying in whole or in part the expenses of the boys or girls who have to be sent to Business Colleges in Montreal to obtain the rudiments of commercial training.

The building formerly used in connection with the Methodist Mission would be available and the only expense involved would be the maintenance and heating of the building and the payment of the teacher's salary, the latter about $800.00 per annum. Having in mind the excellence of the work performed by the Sisters of St. Anne during the few years they have been in charge of these schools, I think there is no doubt that they would make an equal success of a commercial class. They have now on the staff 8 fully qualified Sisters and one Lay teacher without qualifications, who however, has a knowledge of the Indian language and whose services in the primary class are almost indispensable.

My dear Sir,

Immediately upon receipt of your letter I filed an application for a qualified teacher for a Commercial Class and I am pleased to state that I have obtained the services of one of our very best teachers. This Sister has twelve years experience in teaching; she knows French quite well, and all the Commercial subjects are perfectly familiar to her. Under her direction I feel certain the school will be a success. I conferred with the Authorities at the Mother-house regarding salary expected and I was told that in view of the fact that we were lodged, heated, lighted etc here $850.00 would be considered a reasonable salary for this Special Teacher.

I wish to thank you, My dear Mr. Scott, for so generously refunding the amount expended this year for Assistant Teachers in the Schools. I certainly did not expect this mark of consideration on your part, so it is all the more appreciated. I wish to thank you also for the favor of being allowed to employ Assistant teachers when necessary and I beg to assure you that I shall not abuse of the privilege.

The work of painting and repairing the Schools is well under way, and under Mr. Chene's vigilant care every thing is being satisfactorily done. The basement is in perfect condition and we will be able to use it as a waiting room during rain and stormy weather. You just cannot imagine what a great blessing you are
bestowing upon the Teachers in thus providing for the material comfort of their charges.

The question of our accommodations must give you some concern as I understand the Jacobs family want their house. It seems too bad for we were perfectly satisfied here; yet we well understand how unreasonable it would be to rent the house at such an exorbitant rate for only one year when especially a new furnace must be installed. Mr. Brosseau suggested the Patton Estate, and I visited the place in case the question should come up for discussion. I consider the property of more value than this in many respects, but it is not as well suited for our needs; it could, however, be adapted to our wants very easily. Sleeping apartments for twelve adults take up quite a little space in a house; yet unless teachers are comfortably housed and well fed it is most unreasonable to expect good work. If the work of Teachers of this School has been satisfactory to you, these last few years you may consider that the very comfortable home you provided for us has contributed in no small measure to that success. With your broad experience you realized this and while the outlay is somewhat great at the start it pays in the end. Whatever you will decide in the matter will be satisfactory as I know you shall look with especial care to the proper accommodations for the Teachers as an essential factor in producing good and lasting results in educational work.

With renewed thanks for your kindness,

I am, dear Mr. Scott,

Yours very cordially,

[Signature]

To the Gentlemen of the School Branch Department of Indian Affairs:

1. This is the largest registration in the annals of the Schools. Three hundred thirty pupils. In September 1919 we registered 274. Gain of 36 pupils.

2. In September 1919 the percentage of attendance based on enrollment in the Boys' school was 88%. This year it is 93%.

3. In the Girls' school the percentage of attendance is smaller because 15 or 20 girls did not register until the end of the month.

4. By special permission from the Deputy Minister we are allowed to employ Assistant Teachers in the primary grades when necessary. This month we employed two and pay them $30.00 per month.

5. The classrooms are crowded. In the Girls' School, primary room there are 16 x 18 children who have no seats. The maximum capacity of the room is 42 and there are 60. This will ease off in the winter, but in the mean time it is a great inconvenience.

6. I recommend that the Department devise means of opening a new classroom in the spring of 1921. A temporary class might be opened in some vacant house which could be fitted up during the winter, and made ready for the influx in April.
7. Progress is delayed in the Continuation School because the children have no books. I have written and requested the Superintendent of Stationery to kindly give personal attention to our Requisition.

8. Children show more interest in the work and parents hesitate about keeping the children out of school. Truancy is due to neglect of parents rising in time to prepare children for school. There is improvement in this respect.

Respectfully yours,
Sister Mary Gabriel

Dear Sir:

My attention has been recalled to the very large enrolment and average attendance at the Caughnawaga schools and to the necessity of making provision for further classroom accommodation. I am assured by my officers who have visited the reserve during the last few years that these schools are exceedingly creditable institutions. I hope that the Indians are appreciating what the Department is doing for them by way of providing thorough education for their children. There is a limit, however, to the expenditure that the Government should be called upon to make, and it would appear that the time has arrived when the Indians themselves will have to bear at least a portion of the burden, not only in providing additional accommodation if necessary, but also assisting in the maintenance of the schools, including salaries, fuel, etc., etc.

I am writing you to be good enough to bring this up for discussion in your Council at some meeting in the near future, and I shall be glad to know the result of your deliberations.

Dear Mr. Sutherland,

I have had an interview with Mr. Arnot Brossard during which he discussed the situation at the Boys' School. He told me to write to the head of the Schools' Branch, expressing the conditions and asking for instructions as to the course we are to follow.

I already stated that the number of children in regular attendance at the schools had greatly increased, and while the space in the Primary Class of the Girls' School offers facilities for expansion to meet the conditions, no such arrangement can be made in the Boys' School. In this school there are at the present time the following number of children:

| Class | Number |
|-------|--------|
| 1st    | 29 boys - 2 away will return in March |
| 2nd    | 34 "   - 1 away |
| 3rd    | 35 "   - 3 " |
| 4th    | 40 "   - 4 to return |

The seating capacity of the 3rd class is 54, but we may add four seats which we have already done, but the seating capacity of the 4th class is 40 and there are 48 pupils present besides 4 in decline, and 14 or 16 to come as soon as the weather conditions permit. We cannot add another seat here, so the question arises what are we to do? Two courses are open. Either refuse to accept any other children, or rent a room in the vicinity to accommodate them, and this is the proposition I submit to you, and through you, to the other officials who may have a word to say in the matter.

Mr. Brossard will visit this afternoon, a hall which is vacant, and used for social gatherings only; if it is at all suitable, he will report the matter to you, and if it meets your views, we may rent it and get it ready for the term beginning April 1st. Until then we will manage the best we can, and will refuse no pupils until the Department has come to a decision.

I am writing in order to give the Department ample time and opportunity to consider the matter.

Trusting you will give these requests your kind attention.

I am, dear Sir,

Yours respectfully,

My dear Sir,

Would you be good enough to inform me if the Department has reached any conclusion regarding the necessity of opening a class to relieve the congested condition of the Primary Class at the Boys' School. I strongly requested Mr. Agent Brossard to rent the house belonging to Mr. John Delorme which is close to the school, and which he offers for $150.00 per year. Mr. Brossard had thought of his offer but objected because it would be too far away, and it would be impossible for me to give the class the attention it needed. This house would answer the purpose until some steps are taken to enlarge the school here.

You will see by the Report which must have reached you that we have 106 children more registered this March 31st than on a similar date in 1920.

I have been obliged to have many of the old desks repaired and placed in the class rooms to suit the needs.

My dear Sir,

I visited a few days ago the Soldier's Civil Re Establishment office in Montreal in the hope of getting some of the furniture which was picked out early in February, but which we never received, owing to some misunderstanding. I found that almost everything of value had been taken away. There remained a few tables and book together with other odds and ends that I selected for use in the schools here.

I noticed a large quantity of tools of every kind and description, bolts, locks, pans, hammers, axes, shovels, spades, hewing, belting etc etc. The officer in charge told me we could have all we wanted of this stock. Of course I am not competent to judge of what might be useful and suggested sending over Capt. Baker, Mr. Peter Hall, there to select what could be used in the different buildings here. Would you therefore kindly send me a note
authorizing Peter Vian, to select for the Department of Indian Affairs whatever would be useful. The official in charge urged me to take all we could of this stock as they are closing up.

I further noticed several type-writers in good condition, and would gladly have taken two or three, but the Officer stated they had received orders to ship these to the Stationery Department in Ottawa. Do you think you could manage to get a permit of some kind to allow us to get a few of them for our Commercial Class? It would save the expense of sending them to Ottawa, and we surely do not need new typewriters for practice. I think it would be a great economy to obtain these.

I selected a quantity of school material mostly book-keeping blanks, they may be utilized as writing books for our children and if I get all that is there we will be supplied for a few years. The supply sent from Ottawa in January is almost exhausted. I kept some of the most valuable books for ink blanks as I considered it a waste to allow children to scribble on such fine paper. with the old benches etc. There will be
forty boys in this class, and 40 or more

OTTAWA, June 20th, 1921.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, regarding the payment of substitute teachers who were employed during the illness of the regular teachers.

In reply, I beg to say that the method usually adopted is for the full salary to be paid the regular teacher, who arranges with the substitute and pays any salary due. There is a certain amount provided each year for salaries for each school, and it is not possible to pay the regular teacher full salary and also pay a substitute, as there is no money specially provided for this purpose.

When the returns are received for the current quarter, a cheque for the full quarter's salary will be sent in each case, and you can arrange for the payment of any amount due substitute teachers employed.

Enclosed herewith Report for the Schools of Caughnawaga Year ending June 30th.

The total number of pupils on roll in the schools under the direction of Sisters in Caughnawaga village is 408. An increase of 97 pupils over June 1920.

A 5th class was opened on May 30th to accommodate 41 small boys. An assistant was put in charge under the direction of the Sister in charge of 4th class to finish the year. A regular teacher will take charge in September. The 4th class in Hall School is overcrowded. 75 pupils is too much. An additional class would be a necessity.

The attendance in the lower classes fell on account of an epidemic of measles which lasted several weeks. Seven pupils from the Continuation School received their diplomas for stenography from the Stenographic Institute of Montreal. Eight received diplomas for typewriting; three from the Montreal Typewriters Company, and five from the Montreal Institute.

My dear Sir,

I am enclosing a list of the teaching staff of the Caughnawaga Schools showing the salary actually paid the different teachers together with what I consider a reasonable increase.

I must here assure you that these salaries are below what is paid the teachers under the Montreal School board. We conduct nineteen schools there, and each teacher receives $500.00 per annum regardless of the Grade she teaches with a yearly bonus of $100.00 for those who are especially qualified. You readily understand that the Mother house would not give Sisters to teach here unless they receive a salary equal to what is paid in the other schools. Ours is an organization and it must be conducted on business principles or it would quickly cease its activities. The salaries have not been raised since 1917, and our work here has practically doubled. During the war so many families were away or moved away temporarily that the classes were not heavy, now they are over crowded. None but able bodied strong teachers can stand the strain of work here. If I did not make this appeal before it was because the bonus received brought the salaries to a fair level but I wish to signify that no new teachers will be given for the old rates, hence my suggestion of either paying the new teachers $650.00 and $300.00 respectively or raise the salaries of the teachers at the Boys' School according to the scale submitted.

I am, dear Sir,

To the Editor of The Post-Standard:

Dr. A. C. Hill, director of Indian schools in New York state, would do well to visit the Indian schools in Quebec to learn a few things about Indian school management. The Canadian government does not think the fourth grade good enough for an Indian, neither do I. I think the Indians should be taught to write and take part in deportations, etc. The record established by the Indian schools in Quebec is very good and ought to shame the record set by the Indian schools in New York state. The department of Indian affairs has no experience in building and equipping schools on all the Indian reservations in this province and nothing but legally qualified teachers are employed.

On the Caughnawaga reservation there are two fine brick buildings and two frame buildings. These frame buildings are not to be found in the city of Montreal. A school better built or near as good appearance cannot be seen in these brick buildings. The frame buildings are the equal of any to be found in the city of Montreal. There are four classes. Three of these buildings are within a stone's throw of each other, the first, second, third and the fourth is in the western part of the town. Four hundred and seven children of whom are living on the reservation and the average attendance during the year just ending is 385.

The department of Indian affairs considers the Indian advance made to such an extent that it has opened up a continuation school for the more advanced students who have graduated young Indian boys and girls in a general business course which includes stenography and shorthand. Upon the completion of their studies they are furnished with a diploma from a Montreal business school. Seven of these students have been successfully passed the Underwood test and will be given the Underwood diploma.

The pupils in charge of these schools are greatly pleased with their Indian teachers. They say they take great delight in showing visitors through the schools. Visitors are requested to ask the teacher to let a girl step forward and answer any questions that may arise from the years books. That which attracts most attention the most was the discipline displayed by the pupils and also the general appearance of the class rooms and the buildings.

I visited the schools last fall and well, I was told that it was all due to the department of Indian affairs at Ottawa who had been doing so much furnishing teachers with everything that they asked for. No matter what they asked for they always sent them; be it a bunch of pencils or four typewriters, which was the case last winter. Papers, blackboards and desks are all furnished to the children at the expense of the government.

What is it that we have so many complaints on our reservations in New York state with regards to equipment? Why can't we have qualified teachers? Is it strange that we look after the education of the handicapped Indians that are cooped up on reservations to the same degree as we do that more children attend school at Caughnawaga in one year than all the schools in New York state except Indian reservations. What kind of diploma does Dr. Hill give the children that ever do graduate out of his fourth grade?

W. B. NEWELL,
Caughnawaga, Quebec.

My dear Sir,

I wish to call your attention to the condition of the schools here especially in the East end of the village and to ask you what course it would be best to pursue.

There are all told 6 classrooms in this section of the village with seating capacity and attendance as follows:

| Class               | Seats | Attendance |
|---------------------|-------|------------|
| Continuation Class  | 24    | 25         |
| 1st Class, Boys' School | 40   | 38         |
| 2nd "               | 40    | 40         |
| 3rd "               | 44    | 44         |
| 4th "               | 48    | 48         |
| 5th "               | 44    | 47         |

You will see that by the present arrangement there are only two seats available in the last class and these are already retained by boys who have been working all summer and who have signified their intention of returning to school and we are short of 3 seats in the 5th. You will moreover notice that these classes are too heavy and that no teacher can successfully handle so many pupils. Twenty-five children, thirty at most, is all any teacher can manage. Additional classrooms is an immediate necessity and I earnestly request you to give this matter your kind attention. Up to the present I have managed with the aid of two Assistant teachers to keep the classes in working order. I have been obliged to give all my time to relieve the teachers overburdened with work. It could be done as long as we had place to accommodate the children but now every seat is filled as you see.

Two courses are open, the 1st, to refuse any other children; the second, to open another class. With this end in view I have visited two houses where there are rooms large enough to accommodate a class of 30 children. These are available and the proprietors are willing to rent them for $12.50 per month. One a Mr. Snow, the other Mr. John Jacco. Permettez-moi de vous offrir, ainsi qu'à Madame Jacobs et à toute votre famille, mes remerciements pour les attentions que vous avez eues pour moi, et l'hospitalité que vous m'avez offerte lors de mon passage, ces jours-ci, à Caughnawaga.

J'ai d'autant plus de plaisir à vous témoigner ma reconnaissance que vous m'avez fourni l'occasion d'étudier sur place les conditions actuelles des Indiens de la Réserve, et, plus particulièrement, le magnifique essor qui est maintenant donné à l'instruction de leurs enfants.

C'est avec une admiration profonde, et que vous avez remarquée sans doute, que j'ai visité les demeures d'un bon nombre de vos familles, y compris la vôtre, et que j'y ai trouvé le cachet éloquent de la propreté, de l'aisance et de la distinction. Il m'a été donné également de constater la condition des gens moins fortunés, et de trouver chez eux, dans l'en-

semble, des moeurs paisibles et le respect de l'autorité, avec beaucoup de sympathie pour l'étranger qui passe chez eux.

Mais, ce qui m'a frappé pardessus tout, c'est le développement de l'éducation. J'ai visité dans la Réserve, au jour même de l'ouverture des classes, quatre écoles où déjà au-delà de trois cent cinquante enfants se sont inscrits. La tenue de ces écoles, confiée aux Révérendes Soeurs de la communauté de Ste-Anne, m'a parue parfaite, et les élèves y sont pourvus généreusement, aux frais du gouvernement fédéral, de tout ce qui est nécessaire à leur instruction. Ces enfants sont réellement favorisés, et, vous le dirais-je, à les voir si bien installés, ils feraient envie aux enfants qui fréquentent la majorité des écoles de nos campagnes. Au reste, les petits Indiens m'ont paru bien répondre à l'attention qu'on a pour eux. Ils sont tous très propres, se présentent bien, et j'ai constaté moi-même qu'ils sont très avancés dans les études qu'on leur fait poursuivre. On y a décerné, l'an dernier, de nombreux diplômes, et il m'a fait plaisir d'y voir une école d'enseignement commercial avancée, où les jeunes gens peuvent se préparer à remplir des positions lucratives dans les affaires. Dear Mr. Jacobs,

Allow me to offer you, as well as Mrs. Jacobs, and all your family, my thanks for the kind attention you have had for me and for the hospitality which was extended to me during my stay a few days ago at Caughnawaga. It is ever so great a pleasure to express my thankfulness that you have furnished me with an occasion to study on the spot the present conditions of the Indians on the Reserve, and more particularly the splendid impulse which is now given to the education of their children.

It is with deep admiration which you have noticed, surely, that I have visited the dwellings of a good number of Indian families, as well as yours, and I found in them cleanliness, ease and distinction. I also had the opportunity to become acquainted with those who are less fortunate and to find ease with them, generally, peaceful manners and respect of authority, together with a great deal of sympathy for the strangers visiting them.

But, what struck me above all, is the development of education. I visited the reserve on the day of the opening of the classes at the four schools where already more than 250 children were registered. The keeping of these schools which is entrusted to the reverend sisters of the Community of St. Ann's, appeared to me to be perfect and the pupils are generously provided at the expense of the Federal Government of everything necessary for their education.

These children are really favourite and should I tell you that, when seeing them so well provided, their good fortune would be envied by children attending the majority of our country schools. However, the young Indians have appeared
to respond to the kindness extended to them. They are very clean; they stand well, and I found for myself that they were quite advanced in the studies which they are following.

Several diplomas have been awarded last year, and I was greatly pleased to see there, a school of advanced commercial studies where the young people can prepare themselves to fill good business positions. I also learned that many of the pupils were leaving your schools to enter into classic colleges.

All this is obviously due to the good will of your population who have understood the importance of education, but we must also render homage to the religious authorities and to the Government who are so deeply interested in the welfare of the Indians and more particularly to the reverend sisters who are exercising there, an apostleship truly edifying.

I also take liberty to congratulate all the far-seeing minds who with you, on this reserve, have in the later years, helped the generous movements in favour of the advancement of their fellow citizens. What I saw in the schools has given me great hopes for the future of the Iroquois of Caughnawaga. Education which has been so largely spread amongst them in the last few years should make of their descendents, in the near future, a sane and strong people united to the other Canadians, and able to rivalise with them in all the activities of social domains.

I wish to renew, dear Mr. Jacobs, to you and to your family, my best thanks for the delicate object of Indian Art which you have kindly offered me during my visit with you.

Yours devotedly,

(SGD) Gustave Monette,
(Lawyer)

My dear Mr. Perrier,

I am grateful for the prompt reply to my letter and for your kindness in sending the Algebras which I expect to receive soon. I have had some experience with the Stationery Department in the past when books I asked for in January reached us late in June. This was my reason for asking to purchase the books here so that we could get right on with the work, but if you take up the matter with the Stationery Office they will probably give it more attention. "Hall and Knight" is just the author I would wish for.

Our policeman is now following up a clue which I hope may lead to the recovery of the stolen typewriter.

I am pleased to inform you and all the other officials of the Department who may be especially interested in Couchiching that after many repeated efforts I have succeeded in getting a telephone placed in our Residence. The Company will install a private pay station here which will cost nothing to the Department nor to us. We will have to pay only for the calls. It will be a wonderful convenience and time saver. Whenever the Department desires to communicate with the Officials here, the privacy our house affords will be a great advantage. As soon as the installation is completed I shall send the name and number of the telephone to the Department.

On Saturday I brought eleven of our children to Montreal to have their eyes tested. After many repeated efforts I succeeded in getting the parents to provide glasses for their children. Through the influence of personal friend at St. Luke's Hospital they were all examined free of charge by a Specialist. All were in a wretched condition and will need treatment which we will give them here before and after school hours. This is only a beginning in the right direction and I hope other parents will realize the necessity of looking after their children's eyesight. Many are backward in their work on this account.

With renewed thanks,

I am, dear Sir,

My dear Sir,

I have just handed in the quarterly reports of the schools to Mr. Agent Brossard and they will be referred to you in due time.

You will notice that in spite of the bad weather conditions, illness, insufficient clothing and other hindrances the schools have been well filled this quarter. Forty-seven pupils more were registered during the March 1922 quarter than were enrolled in March 1921. The average attendance also increased from 236 in March 1921 to 286 in March 1922.

With the coming of spring, the fine weather and good roads many more children will return, and I am really worried to know how to accommodate them. The teachers are already overtaxed and were it not for the help given by Assistant teachers in some of the class rooms we could not make much headway. We employ two; one to assist in the 4th Class Boys' and Girls' School where 50 children are registered and another who divides her time between the boys and girls school where I think her help most needed. She assists with the backward children and thus relieves the teachers. These young girls help greatly and as they have no employment they are glad to work for a small salary.

Early in the fall of 1921 you told me the Department would open a new class this spring. While this is almost imperative we would not easily find a suitable place and it would cost so much to get it fitted up. If the Department intends building I would suggest that instead of opening a new school this spring, I be authorized to employ a third Assistant for the Primary Girls School, and as the room is large I can place quite a few more desks there and thus carry on the work until the end of this school year. This will save the Department quite an outlay, and perhaps the results will be as satisfactory.
I would call your attention to one family here named Benedict. We are four children of school age and none have attended this year but one for a few months in the early fall. They are in absolute need of help. The father is in the hospital and there is not a cent of revenue in the house. I have given them all the assistance I could in the line of food and clothing, but it seems to me the Department should investigate the matter. I have called the attention of the Agent to these people, and he tells me he has tried in vain to get the children fitted up to come to school. If you can possibly do anything for them it would be a great charity.

I wish to state here in reference to one of your suggestions that we refuse all children under school age, that according to the Indian Regulations I have, the age is from 6 to 15 and I accept children at six. Occasionally I have been obliged to take in a few below that age, but very seldom. It is very hard to refuse or send away children here because the people immediately think you are discriminating against them, and they consequently cause trouble, and if you have any idea of how much trouble such a little thing will cause you will easily understand my attitude.

We are all looking forward to your visit, and when we shall meet and see things as they really are it will be easier to discuss ways and means of improvement. I hope you will have sufficient time at your disposal to make a thorough and complete investigation of the Gaughnawaga Reserve Schools.

I am pleased to state that we now have a long distance telephone with local office at Lachine. The number is 812 - Ring 4. Any time the Department wishes to send a hurried message to Gaughnawaga we will be happy to deliver it.

Trusting that you will find the reports etc. satisfactory in every detail,

I am, dear Sir

Yours respectfully,

Sister Mary Gabriel

Dear Sir:

I wish to thank you for your prompt and kind reply to my letter of April 2nd, and to tell you that I am extremely grateful.

Our school will reopen on April 1st, as the Teachers' Federation has decided to close a week earlier than usual. We had no choice but to follow their lead, as we always try to cooperate with them. The Department has always approved this because it is quite hard to keep the children in school the last week of June when the lure of strawberries, fishing, etc., takes them away from their studies. Another reason is that the "smash" Gulf Stream is in full swing during June and our boys get so excited at the thought of getting them to school. At this time there is nothing to worry about and we feel it is beneficial to the children to have them in school.

I am pleased to tell you that one of our pupils following the Commercial Department of the school has obtained a position as stenographer and typist in a large lumber firm. He would be very pleased helping me to complete a course but the firm demands a little more work and he has $300 a week to start. He wrote 92 words per minute in shorthand and about 45 words per minute on the typewriter.

I regret to state however, that our best pupil in the Commercial Class was stricken with typhoid fever a few weeks ago and will be quite a long time out of school.

Now that the spring is at hand I trust you will soon come here again for your well-earned visit to see the school. We are looking forward to your coming with much pleasure.

Respectfully yours,

Dear Sir:

I enclose, at your request, samples of the letter you dictated to the Stenography class on May 8th. Not any of them are absolutely perfect, but I send them just as they handed them in to the teacher the following day. They received no help whatever from anybody.

I wish to say that all the teachers have kept of your visit a most pleasing remembrance and we will look forward to your coming again whenever an opportunity presents itself. I should request you, when you have time, to send me a written report of your visit here, bearing on methods used, discipline, supervision, conditions existing at the time, etc. Any suggestion for improvement in the methods of teaching will be heartily appreciated and we shall endeavor to follow your directions most faithfully.

Mr. Scott:

I wish to report on my visit to the Caughnawaga Reserve, on the 8th and 9th instant. I found in the village schools a total of 425 pupils enrolled and in attendance 331. The classrooms are crowded, but the buildings are in good condition. The Sister Superior and the Sisters are to be congratulated upon the excellent results that they have obtained. The pupils are bright, clean and are on the whole doing the best work that I have seen in any Indian day schools in Canada.

Boys' School.

There are 172 boys enrolled in the regular classes held in the main building and in the little frame building to the south. Grades 1 to 5 are in these buildings and, although crowded, are doing excellent work.

There is but 1½ acres of school lot in connection with the Boys' School, and I would strongly recommend that the property be graded, filled and drained, so as to provide proper playground facilities. In addition, a chicken netting should be placed along one side for about 30 yards to provide a back-stop for balls which are continually flying over into the neighboring garden.

Continuation Class:

The Continuation Class, doing commercial work, is situated in the Boys' School building. The typewriting is done on the second floor of the little frame structure to the south, and shorthand and other subjects are taught in the main building. This feature of the Caughnawaga school system is unique in Canada, for I believe that no Indian school elsewhere is teaching commercial work. There are 27 boys and girls enrolled in this special class.

Girls' School

In the Girls' School there are classes from the primary grade to grade 6, 2 of them being held in the assembly hall. The seating accommodation is hardly adequate for the large enrolment. The teachers, without exception, are doing excellent work and the pupils are bright and clean and show considerable initiative.
The school lot at the Girls' School should be levelled and drained as soon as possible, to provide proper playground facilities for the 176 girls enrolled. I have authorized a minor repair to the furnace and, over Mr. McLean's signature, the Departmental Engineer, Mr. Chene, was instructed to arrange for a larger water supply pipe from the Mission House under the road to the school. This road was about to be macadamized and the work had to be undertaken immediately.

Boys' and Girls' School.

The building formerly used by the Methodist Church for educational purposes is occupied by 48 primary boys and girls. They show evidence of excellent instruction and will make rapid progress under the tuition of the Sisters. The grounds here are very small and not fit for playground purposes. This school building should be no longer used for educational purposes when more accommodation is provided in a large building elsewhere.

Teachers' Residence.

The teachers' residence is quite adequate for the purpose of housing the 14 Sisters doing the work among the Indian children at Caughnawaga. You will remember that the Department built an addition on the rear of a building for which we hold a 5 year lease. I learned that we hold an option on this front portion for $2,000 and, if this is considered a good purchase by the Departmental Architect, it should without question be taken over, in view of the improvements that we have made. If we purchase the front portion of the building or if we are committed to such action, the outside wall should be given a coat of marine paint and the roof of the barn should receive some repairs.

Janitors

I found that the Sisters and the Agent were quite pleased with the services rendered by the 2 Janitors, Messrs. Vieux and Zacharie. In the case of the last named employee, I would recommend that his salary be increased from $250 to $300 per annum, in view of his faithful and excellent services.

Truant Officer

The most energetic and businesslike employee of the Department on the Caughnawaga Reserve is John K. Jocks, Constable and Truant Officer. Every child absent from school is checked up immediately, and this officer is putting all his time on departmental work. He receives, as Constable, $60 a year and, as Truant Officer, $200. In view of the excellent results that he has shown, I would recommend that his salary as Truant Officer be increased by $100.
Congested Classrooms.

The buildings in use for school purposes on the Caughnawaga Reserve are adequate for all the Indian wards between the ages of 7 and 15 years. 3 factors combine to keep the schools crowded - first, the untiring energies of the Truant Officer - second, the enrolment of 20 five-year-old and 53 six-year-old pupils. In view of the splendid results with which the Sisters are meeting in the primary grades, I hesitate to recommend that these younger children be discharged from the schools. The Department has permitted, for some time, those of 6 years to attend. The 20 five-year-olds have been carefully selected by the Sister Superior from the many applicants for admission at this age. The five-year-olds at school have lost either one or two of their parents or come from homes where they are receiving absolutely no oversight.

The third factor in connection with the crowded classrooms is the presence of French children who are not wards of the Government. As I visited the classrooms, I made a survey of those in this category and, with the help of the Agent, Truant Officer, Priest and Sister Superior, found 20 white children in attendance. The Indian Council, when I met them on the evening of the 9th, assured me that there were many more than this number attending the Indian schools. I informed the Council that the Department had more or less a moral obligation to those whom we permitted to lease reserve lands in connection with the education of their children.

The great need at Caughnawaga is another building with 6 classrooms and an auditorium. One room could be used for the Grade 6 boys and girls, one room each for primary boys and girls and two rooms for the commercial class. The third floor could be used as an auditorium. This building should be placed on a site with adequate playground facilities.

Meeting with Council and Band.

At the request of the members of the Council, I attended an unofficial council meeting at which 150 members of the Band were present, on the evening of the 9th instant. I reported on my inspection of the schools and congratulated the Band on the excellent progress that was being made and on the evident interest of the parents.

In answer to a request that the boys of the village be taught by lay teachers - preferably men - I informed the Council that the Department has absolute confidence in the Sisters and that I could take no recommendation to Ottawa regarding a change.

The most important matter broached by the Council was the large number of French children attending the schools and overcrowding the classrooms. I explained that the Department had a moral obligation to those whom we permitted to lease land on the reserve; and that, when visiting the school, I had counted only 25 who were not wards of the Department. The Indians felt that there were more than this number in attendance and they asked permission to visit the schools in an effort to verify their statements.
statements. In the light of the Sister Superior's expressed willingness to allow the members of the Council to come into the schools and get acquainted with the work, I promised the Council that I would strongly recommend that they be given permission to visit.

The members of the Council strongly urged the opening of a night class in technical education for the older boys of the village. They requested that particular emphasis be placed on the reading of blue prints and other studies related to structural work. I promised to give this matter earnest consideration and suggested that they cast about for a suitable man - preferably in Caughnawaga - who was qualified to give such instruction.

The Council claimed to be strongly interested in the education of the children of the Band and asked that a School Board be appointed. I informed them that the powers of such a Board would naturally be limited, because the entire expense was being met by the Vote for Indian Education. I intimated that it might be possible, if the parents of the children were interested enough, to arrange for a School Board with the powers of visitation and recommendation. The Council asked me to draft regulations covering the duties and functions of such a School Board.

My dear Sir,

There are here two groups of Indians, bitterly opposed one to the other. It is sufficient for one group to approve a measure for the other to disapprove it for no other reason very often than to stir up a little commotion. As a consequence, there are living here families whom one group recognize as Indians, but the others claim them to be white. One group is opposed to Government control and want to return to olden traditions, the other wants improvements and generally show satisfaction at what the Department decides. One group approves the church and sustains the Missionary, the other criticizes everything that is done. One group approves the schools, admires the work of the teachers, the other condemns wholesale everything that is being done. I have tried to follow the middle course and favor neither one nor the other. The younger people show a different spirit, and are not so antagonistic. I am in hopes that time will better these conditions, and education will do a great deal towards broadening the minds of the Indians.

Once again assuring you that should the Gentlemen of the Council present themselves, we will give them a warm welcome.

I am, dear Sir,

Sir.—
I was present at the closing Exercises of the Schools in Caughnawaga last evening (June 21st) and heartily applauded your high tribute to Reverend Sister Mary Gabriel the retiring Principal of the Caughnawaga Reserve Schools. None more than I regret that circumstances should thus deprive the schools of such an active painstaking and devoted Supervisor, and it occurred to me that in view of the many years of faithful service to the Department I would beg to make a suggestion in her behalf. You are aware that she is leaving early in July and since the Canadian National Railways run across to Vancouver would you not be in a position to obtain from the Minister of Railways a pass for herself and her companion that would enable her to travel on the Government Railways free of cost. This, I think would be a tangible proof of your appreciation of her services past and ensure those of the future as I understand she will still be in touch with Government work.

This act might have further reaching results as the Order of which she will be the official head in British Columbia travels to and from Montreal quite frequently. Every summer over twenty Sisters come East for their vacation. The patronage which they have hitherto given to the Canadian Pacific Railways might be by this act diverted to the Canadian National Railways.

Furthermore it would give me an opportunity of being the instrument by which such a concession would be made and I would be highly pleased to offer this as a tribute to Sister Mary Gabriel.

As the time is very short and travelling heavy at

Whereas we want to establish at your satisfaction the following facts:

1- That Sam Simpson, a boy of ten years old, was ordered beaten as a punishment by the boys of his class under the authority of the sister Superior with closed fists causing him to have a swollen lip and a bruise above the left eye, two days before the closing of the classes.

2- That Peter D'Aillebout, 8 years of age during winter 1923, was ordered by the sister Superior to have his thumb pressed against burning coal as a punishment.

3- That John D'Aillebout, a protestant pupil, was ordered by the nuns to attend the Catholic Church and disregard any instructions to the contrary which might be given him by his father or mother, and this happen many times during the last ten months.

4- Mike Nolan, 5 years of age, during Christmas Time 1923, was taken by the orders of the nuns in squatting position and raised above a hot stove and lowered on it in same position several times causing him a terrible fright and distress. Later on, the nuns pressed his thumb against the hot stove.

5- That Jos. Deer, a sick child, was punished at school by tying him together with five other children with ropes and forced to stand in the hall with the doors open in cold winter with no hat and no overcoat on. Against later on he was beaten by sister Superior upon the skin with a heavy stick.

6- That Michel Deer, 8 years old, was refused to go out on the 14th of May 1923 and unable to wait had to soil his clothes. He was then ordered by the sister Superior to clean himself, and because unable to do so the sister Superior beat him with a stick and his head against the wall of the school.

7- That 8 days before close of school, sister Superior drops ten boys from their classes at above ten o'clock in the morning and allowed them to live the school, to go to the Golf Club for the whole day.

Whereas all these facts request an enquête, we pray your honor that justice be done.

Sir,— I beg to inform you that one of the pupils of the Caughnawaga village schools, a boy named Dehorn aged 13 years and in attendance since the re-opening of the classes the 4th instant, is a cause of a continued annoyance to the teacher in charge of that class. This boy being tall & bad habits is leading his school mates to ill-use the Reverend Sister who is becoming so nervous over this state of affair and is getting sick. Dehorn used to loudly command his school fellows in Iroquois language during class hours, this, when his moment seems fit to deal against the Reverend teacher who do not understand him in this language, therefore she is a cause of laughter from the young rebels.

I presume that these insubordinates are taking advises from their Indian parents who are presently aimless, or recreants who are trying to persuade a very few other Indians that the Reverend Sisters should be chased away from the Caughnawaga Indian reserve.

I beg to ask your most urgent advise as to the better way to have this boy punished for an example and the welfare of his followers.

I may add that I am not presently acting on behalf of the Reverend Sister Superior who is using all her possible means to overcome these difficulties.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent
