Respected Sir,

I feel intensely anxious to have to make the following disclosures imposed upon me as a duty of conscience, in view of the recent deplorable troubles in Caughnawaga. I do so relying as ever on your honor and that of the esteemed Superintendent in whose integrity I have confidence. I address him thus, you know he is unable here to control. I have not written to him, for I did not know that I have informed him of the following, it would prove disastrous to me. When I was in Caughnawaga the Indians in general were well and even seemed proud of their schools. Mrs. Joseph Edward, my sister-in-law unsuited for the position. Her instruction was limited that I should feel confident to say how little she does know. She taught music rudiments and is incapable of directing the studies of a child. Her inability and poor health were presumably the cause of her neglecting her classes which she did not merit any of reputation. In short she was a failure. The Indians realized her incompetency. She was dismissed by all, and they made several attempts to have
he removed, and to have me return to the school, the present, lying in St. Anne Hospital, Montreal, after a most serious operation. It seems inevitable that she is doomed to return to Caughnawaga as soon as she is able. A protean Superior has been appointed until her return. Father Cass holds to having her return to Canada because she is close to his mother in keeping Sister Eileen, a great friend of his. Father Cass and Sister Eileen may be taken possession of without any change because I wanted to have Sister replaced by a nice person who could do better work with large Indian boys. Last August we got back to Caughnawaga after two weeks' contract, but Eileen fell ill, resulting in affection of the throat and of the vocal cords. Her voice was almost extinct, yet she could take her place another teacher and kept on doing good work. Last February she was sick that the boys had to go to her in the cement, she could not go out. As there was no equipment then instruction was confined to written work. In April a young inexperienced nun was sent to help Sister to take her class while she rested. At the instance of Father Cass, Sister Eileen is returning to Caughnawaga in charge of the large boys although her physician has permitted complete rest, nothing whatever. I need not add that (if anyone wishes to do her work) there is not only an imposition upon the Government, but also an injustice to the Indians and should not be tolerated. I am not prepared to say that Father Cass is
loyal to his people when for his personal gratification he suggests such an arrangement. It is to be regretted that Father is not more careful in his dealings with the Indians. If he could only try to win their over. I do not speak from any feelings ill will towards the Reverend Father or the Indians. I have invariably been kind to them. The Indians seem not pleased with the schools while I was with them, and Mr. Delisle once spoke ill in public of the schools of me. He said to Sr. Joseph Edward that she was incapable being principal of the schools; it humbles me to say he was right. I felt distressed all appear to have those poor people come to me with complaints of the schools. They would say that everything was broken up; the rule was irregular, discipline was lax, physical training had been discarded. Seeing in the Girls' School was neglected and that there was irregular schedule of learning. The boys would come to corroborate their parents complaints, adding that the timetables had not been followed up. Phonics and other subjects had been left out. The Indians having witnessed the work that had been accomplished the year before criticized the Sisters and the priest. Father says will say that very few are against the schools while few are in favor of them today. The people came here to beg me to return. They tell me the Indians want me to resume my work. They assure me that if I were in C., the troubles would cease. I believe them for I know I had the confidence of the tribe. To get along with them, one must be liked.
My success was also due to the fact that I made the Indians understand I was following as closely as possible the precepts of the Department for the Schools. I felt grieved, harassed over the School troubles for which I am not at all responsible. I worked conscientiously for the Indians as well as for the Government. If I had the disposition to run these peculiar and difficult people, surely had it to live in peace with a few ladies who had made me an object of kindness. I was not any too keen with them, I was kind, but exacted good work in the schools, and in that I was right. I was urged on my removal from Longnauage, and I have the right to exonerate myself. I could return without the least embarrassment, I had no disputes with Father Cass. It was also said that I am now incapacitated for work. I am in excellent health, enjoying the same vitality and energy which I need for the welfare of the Indians.

Mother Melanie or Superior General accepted the charge of the Longnauage School counting on me as being the best prepared to undertake the education of Indian boys.

Influenced by false reports she withdrew me, but afterwards regretted her haste. If you do not want the troubles to go on forever, the only way to finish with them is to act firmly with Mother General. The temporary superior holds a diploma, but as the Indians are so badly disposed it would require one in whom they have confidence to win them over. If the Government insist upon my returning to pacify the Indians since the future are responsible to a certain extent for the trouble I am ready to do so. Mr. Scott may inform whom he pleases that he knows from me that I am in Seattle. Please pardon this long letter so badly written.
The supreme effort I am making to write it renders me very nervous. Nothing but a grave sense of duty could induce me to speak so. Each word has been weighed and placed before committed to paper. I regret I can not receive acknowledgment of it, this letter, but I shall be compensated by the good resulting from it, for I am deeply interested in the welfare of the Longhouse People. I shall always cherish a grateful remembrance of Revd Mr Scott whose appreciation of my work in C. is a reward of my service to the Department of Indian Affairs. To you, dear Sir MacKenzie, I offer my renewed thanks for past kindness.

Sincerely,

With high consideration,

Yours most gratefully,

Sister Mary Edward.

I have confidence in His Excellency, Exce. Sturgis and I would not object to his knowing it was I who reported conditions in Longhouse.

Sr. M. Edward.
Most esteemed Sir,

Pardon me if I interrupt you in your important duties, but ever since the events of last Spring concerning my return to Cangahawaga I have desired to write you particularly so, since I have been informed that Mr. Delisle lacks any letter to him to Ottawa. I hope, through Mr. Scott, that you do not consider me unfit to be let in Gabriel's or our absence to supervise her. Such matters seem strange to me. While advised you confidentially of Sr. Joseph Edward's incompetency, I complied with the dictates of conscience. I wrote to Mr. Delisle activated by similar motives. I spoke, perhaps rather openly, but did so in view of hastening matters to a prompt decision for I am kept here without a position, though considered the most prepared in our Sisterhood for the management of these schools. Then again, the trouble has been going on too long. The Indians claim that Sr. Gabriel is wanting in control over the boys that the latter are not submissive and give much trouble to the Sisters. Knowing
that Sister Gabriel, though a good teacher, is not a disciplinarian, and gives but ordinary formation to children. I give evidence to that which was said by so many. I also know that several of the largest scholars had left the school dissatisfied. I am very sorry the principal has not the confidence she would get more respect to congratulate her than to inform of her. The boys need a firm hand over them for they do not fear much the head officer nor the Father. Sister is described by her staff as being partial in the expression, rough and ready—not particular in the teaching of sound instruction etc.

Father has made everything to Sister Helen remaining in Laughlinaga without considering that the school question is too serious a problem to be treated lightly. He thinks perhaps he is right. I never had any liking with him—my matters and was always respectful to him. However deception has been carried too far for both Father and our Brother General. Mother Melanie knew that I am in good health every way and well able to work. The Bishop would have been pleased to serve the Government but is not aware of my returning to C., but, I presume he also was deceived. Today, the whole thing is known in Laughlinaga, and for this reason the Indians are persistent in their purpose. As the first responsibility of the schools depends up
Sir, you will be well aware that there was something of importance to them. I believe he had not attended publicly to any letter to him or probably would be at work in the school today. He merely stated he had received a letter from a lady of leisure—she did not name me—but his remarks gave occasion to a number of me by those interested in having things as they are.

Much esteemed Sir, I have long desired to give you this explanation though it is most painful for me to speak so. I do so in full confidence in your honor and discretion as a gentleman. Regretted having written this before but I will know I shall never be sorry for having addressed you this confidential communication. I have not heard one word of any former letter to you, and I feel grateful for your kind consideration of me. I regret that I cannot be the hope of securing acknowledgment of this.

Wishing you esteemed and kind Sir, and Yours God's choice blessings on the opening of the coming Christmas season.

With the highest consideration,

Yours most respectfully,

Sister Mary Edward.

Most esteemed Sir,

Pardon me if I seem intrusive in addressing you again in reference to the Kanginawaga School. It is the interest stake on them that urges me to communicate to you remarks made me by the Indians themselves regarding the three Indian girls employed as teachers in the schools.

Annie Jacobs, daughter of Mr. Frank Jacobs, has been in charge of the second class in the Girls' School since last January though unqualified for the position. Annie Leboeuf and Miss Regie teach the two primary classes, the latter in the Boys' School, the former in the Girls' School. These girls can not develop language in young children when they have so very little themselves. No worse precedent could be given than to introduce them into the schools as teachers of English. The people have no confidence in them; they say: "These girls are not fit to be teachers, they do not know any more than we do." It appears to me that it is lowering the standard of the schools.
to have such persons on the staff. Sister Dr. Gabriel once claimed that she has no accommodation for white teachers. I had two, they took their meals at the convent and I rented a bedroom for them in one of the best families. An Indian girl could have been engaged by the Sisters to teach catechism in English one hour every day, in each of those primary classes, to help prepare the children for first communion.

We assured good Mr. Scott, that in the present case as well as in everything else of which I have written you regarding myself or concerning the school, I have spoken the truth. When Cunningham showed a deep interest in the Indians and it was solely for their welfare that I have spoken. Before concluding I must repeat my sincere thanks to you, esteem me for having reposed the entire confidence I had reason to place in you, most worthy and devoted Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Sincerely,

With the highest consideration,

Yours most respectfully,

Sister Mary Edward.

My dear Mr. Scott,

Your letter of some few weeks ago relative to the employment of Iroquois girls as Teachers in the schools has given me some little preoccupation and concern, and I delayed writing until I could see what could be done in the matter.

I would first call your kind attention to the fact that qualified teachers will not come to Caughnawaga for the salary given in the three primary grades, viz. $200, $350. Moreover the best qualified teacher, be she a University Graduate, is powerless before 40 or 50 children who do not understand a word she is saying, hence the necessity of having Iroquois girls as interpreters.

I have talked the matter over with the authorities at our Mother-house and have secured the services of two extra Sisters to fill the places of the lay teachers, but neither of them know the language, nor are they willing to devote their time to learning it when the demands for higher qualifications are so pressing. I will be under the necessity of employing Iroquois girls as substitutes and interpreters in the two lower classes if I wish any progress to be made, but they will be under the direction of Sisters who will take charge of the classes.

There are here two groups of Indians arraigned against each other in bitter enmity. If a girl is chosen from one group it excites the displeasure of the other for no other reason than that she belongs to the opposite party. The complaints made by the Indians were based on this, for the girls employed did very good work and gave entire satisfaction as the Inspector's report will prove. Besides they worked and taught under my direct and
Immediate supervision, and they were not senior pupils, but full grown girls, one of them 26 years old, who has been teaching in the schools since 1915 with good results.

Would you not consider, my dear Mr. Scott, that the salaries of the teachers in the lower grades might be raised to meet the demands created by existing conditions? It is true that the bonus last year helped greatly, but should that be withdrawn, it would be difficult to carry on the work of the schools satisfactorily, especially as you hold to having qualified teachers in all the classes.

Trusting that my explanation of the situation will be satisfactory to you, and that my request will meet with your approval,

I am, dear Mr. Scott,

Yours very cordially,

Sister Mary Gabriel

Dear Mr. Smith,

I have to thank you for letting me read the attached letter. We had been dealing with the application of certain Protestant Indians for a day school on the Caughnawaga Reserve. I hope to come to some conclusion about it before long. As you are aware, there is a large majority of Roman Catholics on this reserve, and there is no stable number of Protestants that can be actually counted as such. While there are a few consistent Protestant families, their number fluctuates as they obtain recruits from dissatisfied Roman Catholics. The Protestant day school at Caughnawaga was closed in June, 1919, with full concurrence of the Methodist Missionary Society, who were associated with us in the management. The main reason for closing the school was the poor attendance. The interests of the Roman Catholic or Protestant minority are protected by the law, and we endeavour to provide the minority with schools. I hope before long to have a Protestant school opened on the reserve.

It is altogether likely that this letter was sent to the editors of other newspapers, and I am prepared to find it in print, but I have to thank you for letting me see it and giving me the opportunity of preparing an answer.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Caughnawaga, March 6, 1924.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of sewing material, crochet cotton, silk, etc., which I received from Halifax and Toronto. I wish to thank you most sincerely for sending us all this material which will be very useful and which we will turn to very best account.

I am sure after such a long silence, a little news about the Schools will interest you. There has been a great deal of sickness among the children since January. Colds, grippe, sore throat, measles and especially the itch which is due largely to sanitation. Sometimes the pupils are weeks out of school with that disease because they are not properly dictoried. We have eight pupils in the hospital. I visited them Sunday. All are on the speedy road to recovery excepting Tom Albany, a smart and good boy of fourteen, who has heart trouble and Ida Mayo who I think is threatened with tuberculosis.

The St. Isidore Road School opened last week with an attendance of twelve pupils out of twenty. The terrible snow storm kept many away for a few days.

I have taken monthly examinations in all the classes and the results have been most gratifying. I am astonished at the work accomplished with such a class of children.

I will be absent from March 18th to the 29th, to attend the annual retreat and lectures given to the Principals of our Order. Special lectures are given concerning the important work of directing schools. As we are required to give an account of our Schools, may I ask if the Government intends to better the conditions of Delormier School for the next scholastic year? If there is a question of a new school, will the Department expend any money to repair the Schools and beautify the surroundings?

Thanking you once more for your great kindness,

I am, dear Sir,

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

This faithful and efficient staff of Teachers that show heroic courage in leading young and plastic minds to what is good and noble, have not the least bit of consolation or gratefulness from the Indians of Caughnawaga, who are so unreasonable, exacting and ungrateful.

General proficiency and high moral tone prevail.

Without being presumptuous, I believe our Schools in Caughnawaga can compete with any school of the white race. The result is the one of our devoted and painstaking Sisters. I know the Department appreciates, by comparison, the thorough Christian Education with the careless, less refined development so common in many schools today.

The Mother General of the Order begged Sister Superior of the Caughnawaga Day Schools to ask for an increase of salary for some of the Sisters, I approve that movement because I wonder why they are not paid the salary of lay teachers, who have neither their experience, their capacity, their solicitude nor their interest. For instance, Miss Martin is getting a much larger salary than all the teachers, excepting one. I can say conscientiously that the latter is not doing half as good work, discipline and formation are wanting.

The work done by the Sisters in Caughnawaga is gratifying to the Department as it is a credit to their noble calling.

I feel sure that you will favourably consider my request for a readjustment of the teacher's salaries in the Village of Caughnawaga.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I am rather late in notifying you of the illness of one of my teachers, but actually I have had my hands full lately. Sr. M. Oswald, teacher of the second class at the Girl's School was taken sick suddenly April 26th. Her condition being critical I had her brought to the Incline Hospital in the ambulance and the doctors found her case urgent so that she was operated on immediately.

It was utterly impossible to get a teacher for that class for the salary paid Sister Mary Oswald, ($40.00/month). After many pleadings I succeeded in getting one for fifty-five ($55.) a month. For the fiscal year 1923-24 the average salary was $450, which was supplemented by a bonus of $150. The average salary for female teachers in Quebec towns for the calendar year 1922 was $494.

There was an enrolment for the past fiscal year of 381 with an average attendance of 331 - a good showing. Indian Day Schools, the costs are remarkably low.

The average salary in 1914-15 was $400; in 1920, $412; in 1923-24, $450. The increase has not been rapid and I believe that an increase of $50 teacher is in order as from the beginning of this fiscal year. The salaries for 1924-25, if this recommendation is carried out, would total $7,500.

It will be seen at a glance that the Caughnawaga salaries have not increased as much as the salaries in other Indian day schools in Canada, when I point out that in 1914-15 we voted the salaries for 236 schools at $102,910, while in 1924-25 the salaries at 251 schools are voted at $177,100.

Dr. Scott,

The Public School Inspector, the Indian Agent and the Principal have urged a general increase in salary for the Sisters at the Caughnawaga R. C. Indian Day School. There was an enrolment for the past fiscal year of 381 with an average attendance of 331 - a good showing. The total cost was $13,215, exclusive of the bonus, or an average cost per 15 regular pupils of $556. Considering the amount of work that is being done at the Caughnawaga R. C. Indian Day Schools, the costs are remarkably low.

There are at the school one principal, 11 Sisters, and 3 lay teachers. The total salary which is paid to the principal is $6,750. I wish to recommend a $500 increase or a total of $7,250 for the fiscal year 1924-25. This will result in an average salary of $483.33. (this figure does not include the bonus.)

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

I understand that Mr. Chene is to proceed to Caughnawaga on duty, and, as no provision has been made for the special classes that were held on the Delormier building, I feel that a decision is timely concerning the question of temporary accommodation.

Cloud, owner of a building opposite the teacher's residence, for one year's rental. He has signified willingness to rent for $150 per annum.

Mr. Letourneau estimates the alterations and decorating to the Cloud property at $500, but I believe that the work can be done for less. I also recommend that Mr. Chene receive your authority to undertake the alterations and decorating that are necessary for our purposes.

Dear Sir:

This letter is to inform you that the doctor advises me to take a few weeks' rest. My condition is not serious now but to avoid a long siege of illness it is expedient for me to put aside all work and worry. Therefore, I shall leave for our Sanatorium at Val David, Thursday, Oct. 2nd.

Although everything is straightened out and the schools in good order, I foresee one drawback to the fine attendance we usually have, and that is having a new truant officer who has no experience with these stiff necks. I repeat again, that I am very sorry that the Government did not retain Mr. Jocks' services and assuredly we will be the losers. Already the pupils feel there is no truant officer and in some boy's class, yesterday, seven were absent; that never happened before.

Would you please allow me to purchase a few dozen of second hand Bible Histories at half price? With a little repairing they will be as good as new.

I received the Spellers and Report Cards for which I thank you.

We are expecting the school inspector, Mr. Cuddihy, next Monday.

Thanking you for your past kindness,

I am,

Respectfully yours,

INDIAN AGENT, DATED DECEMBER 23, 1924, ON THE
CAUGHNAWAGA INDIAN DAY SCHOOLS.

The Reverend Supervising Principal, Sister Mary
Rose Alma, has asked several times if Article 10 of
the Indian Act could not be amended. Why not impose
a fine if a child is out more than one day without
permission, also a fine if the same child comes in tardy.
Many parents are very obstinate in sending their children
after all their chores are finished, so those children come
in daily between 9:30 and ten o'clock. The parents reply
that they are their children and that they can keep them
as long as they need them. How can those children learn or
make progress when they lose one hour of school every day.
I hope you will take this matter into consideration and help
conditions. The Sisters' work as hard to make their
pupils advance, we should do all in our power to lighten
their task so difficult with such stiff-necks.
My dear Mr. Ferrier,

Man proposes and God disposes. Such is my case regarding my trip to Ottawa; therefore I will not have the pleasure of my long desired interview with you concerning the pupils and schools of the Caughnawaga Reserve until your visit which I hope will be before early spring.

Concerning the teaching of domestic science, I find it would be extravagant to make a considerable outlay if the Department intended to build a new school next year.

Since we have no electricity from now until the end of the year we could give theory lessons in culinary art in the typewriting room. It is large enough and the typewriting tables could be used instead of desks. Of course it would
be necessary to have a kitchen cabinet so as to have the most needed utensils and the measures for the proportions.

A kitchen cabinet, medium size, good quality costs from one hundred forty-five dollars up.

May I expect to hear from you soon as I should like to have the matter settled before school re-opens.

Wishing you a year full of health, success and prosperity,

Believe me, dear Sir,
Respectfully yours,
Sister Mary Rose Anna

My dear Sir:

The pupils have returned in large number after their well deserved holidays. So far we have had very little sickness considering the cold weather, bad roads, and poor clothing.

I beg to make the following report on the Caughnawaga Indian Day Schools, for Quarter ended March 31st, 1925.

The pupils have been absent a great deal this quarter through sickness. The itch is a plague here. I am happy to hear that Reverend Sister Superior has given an impetus towards hygiene, which is lacking among the Iroquois in general.

The pupils have worked well in spite of all unpleasant happenings on the Reserve. The spirit is much better; education is making progress rapidly, therefore broadening the minds of so many stiff-necks and ignorant Indians, who are happy only when on the war-path.

One boy, Thomas Deerhouse, who is bright, very industrious and reliable, and three girls, Annie Barbes, Julia Saylor and Emma Canadian, all intelligent, diligent and trustworthy, are competing their Second Year Continuation Class and are well prepared for a higher education. The little Iroquois children sang and recited in French and English with ease and grace, at the commencement exercises of the school conducted by the Sisters of St. Ann this week in Kateri Tekakwitha's Hall, Caughnawaga. Montreal, June 27, 1926.

My inspection of the schools and classes of Caughnawaga, under the direction of the Sisters of St. Ann, pleased me very much. The average attendance for the year speaks eloquently of the devotion of the Sisters and the attraction of the school for the pupils. They conducted themselves in the school and on the street like little ladies and little gentlemen.

The copies, drawings and maps of the pupils deserve a high note of appreciation. The weakness in Arithmetic, noted last year, has disappeared and the results are first class. I would note specially for praise and commendation the continuation classes, wherein the pupils answered equally well in Arithmetic, Geography, History of Canada, English dictation, English Composition and typewriting, as well as the best of the same grade in Montreal. A couple of the lower classes fell below the high standard in reading, due, I am sure to overcrowding. At least two more lower classes are needed.

Miss Regis and Mrs. Beauvais deserve praise for the very satisfactory results obtained by their pupils.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

I wish to report on my recent visit to the Caughnawaga R. C. Indian Day School. I made a special study of the question of accommodation that is needed for this activity. At present, classes are conducted in four buildings: 1. the Girls' School; 2. the Boys' School; 3. the former Protestant School; 4. the building we are renting. As we hope to release the third mentioned building for Protestant Day School next year and as the rented building is wholly unsuitable, I gave first attention to the best use of the accommodation in the two brick buildings, the Boys' and the Girls' Schools. Four classes can be accommodated in the Girls' building if the roof is raised. The rooms on the second floor of the Boys' School are not suitable for classroom purposes and can be used for typewriting and domestic science. The classrooms on the first floor are quite suitable. The two old buildings, therefore, look after six classes, but ten classrooms are required, as follows:

First Grade - 2 classrooms,
Second Grade - 2 "
Third Grade - 2 "
Fourth Grade - 1 classroom,
Fifth Grade - 1 "
Sixth Grade - 1 "
Continuation - 1 "

This means, of course, coeducation practically throughout the whole school. It is true that there are two classrooms for each of the three first grades; but my suggestion to the Sister Superior was that they have boys and girls in each and divide the reserve so that the little children would be studying in the closest buildings.

The Sister Superior has lately written that she believes a still further classroom is necessary, due to the large increase expected in the continuation group for the academic year 1927-28. I have answered her letter, pointing out that it might be possible to organize the work so that the extra room would not be needed.

In addition to the ten classrooms, a domestic science room and a typewriting room, the school should have an auditorium. As four classrooms and an auditorium are required in the new building, this suggested to Mr. Chene a two storey building with four classrooms on one floor and an auditorium on the other. The small room might be set off as an office. When it is known exactly what accommodation is really necessary, I shall prepare another memorandum. The September enrolment and average attendance of 322 and 311, respectively, indicates that ten classrooms is the minimum accommodation required.

Supt. of Indian Education

MEMO RE EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITY ON THE CAUGHNAWAGA INDIAN RESERVE

Caughnawaga Village R. C.

This day school activity is conducted in four separate buildings, two of which have several classrooms by the Sisters of St. Ann. There are 12 Sisters and 3 lay workers in our service. The enrolment for the past fiscal year was 351 and the average attendance, 285.

Caughnawaga Bush R. C.

This school is a one-classroomed affair, on the outskirts of the village and is conducted by a lay worker. The enrolment is 30 and the average attendance, 25.

St. Isidore R. C.

Another one-roomed school, on the outskirts of the village, conducted by a lay worker; enrolment - 16; average attendance - 14.

The total enrolment at the Roman Catholic schools of the village is 397, with an average attendance of 324, or 81.3 percentage of attendance - a very creditable record. The Department of Indian Affairs considers this day school activity one of the most efficient in Canada. The Catholic work has been conducted without break for about a hundred years. Part of this time the Government did not pay any grant. The Sisters of St. Ann have been in charge the last twelve years. There is now in operation a well attended class for high school and commercial students.

Protestant School

A one-roomed school in the village with an enrolment of 34 and an average attendance of 24. This school was formerly conducted by the Methodist Church. The Government commenced grants in 1899. In 1919, it was closed.
for lack of attendance. In 1924, there was an urgent request for the re-opening of a Protestant school, and one which is undenominational in character was commenced. The class is conducted in the Methodist Church building, as the school formerly used for Protestant purposes was required in 1920 to take care of the increasing enrolment at the R.C. school.

It is the intention to conduct Catholic work on this reserve in only five buildings - the two on the outskirts of the village at St. Isidore and Bush and three brick buildings in the village, two were erected some years ago and it is proposed to build the third in 1927. The old Protestant classroom building will then be released for the present Protestant school activity.

Sir:

Evidently the new school will not be ready for many months and you are aware that our former St. Ann's School and the rented school house are no longer to be used by us, therefore taking away three class rooms. Where shall we teach?

Our decision of co-operation throughout the classes necessitates some change in the girls' school especially, and unless immediate attention is given to the work, it will be utterly impossible to start school at the beginning of the term. Several other questions need to be discussed before I organize the classes for the next school term.

Should it be impossible for you to come to Caughnawaga, I would rather sacrifice a day or so and go to Ottawa than delay the opening of school.

Awaiting an early reply, I am my dear Sir,

Sir:

My dear Sir,

I have given serious reflection and consideration to your letter of December 21st in which you asked if it would be advisable to employ a male teacher for the instruction of the more advanced boys attending the Caughnawaga Indian Day Schools. I have examined the question from every educational point of view and really do not consider it advisable nor worth while expending money for a male teacher for a handful of boys who continue their course. When the Continuation School numbers twelve boys, it is a large class. Most Iroquois boys are eager to discontinue their schooling on their fifteenth birthday, that accounts for the small number of boys in the upper classes.

The insinuation of the Councillors that Higher Arithmetic is not taught is very false. The inclosed marks obtained by the pupils of the upper classes at the semi-annual examinations of the General Prefect of Studies of our Order, two weeks ago, will reveal the truth.

My opinion is that if the Department opened a College course on the Reserve, then that would have a good effect on the lives of those boys who having completed the course of studies in our schools would be under the care and training of male teachers for a number of years. My experience with Iroquois boys convince me that only a religious order of men can face the situation and make it a success. If a decision to that effect should take place, many changes would be required all around: schools, habitation, teaching staff of Sisters.

Before taking a final decision, do you not think an interview to discuss such important matter would be much more satisfactory to the Department and to myself.

Yours very truly,

My dear Sir,

It will interest you to hear that the opening of the academic course on February 6th was the realization of the desire of many mothers but especially that of our former graduates. The innovation stirred up the dormant brains of many.

An unexpected large number responded to the invitation of continuing their course, but as accommodations were limited, only nine could be accepted. LA DANSE DU SOLEIL

La grande famille iroquoise veut une église digne de Catherine Tekakwitha, le lis des Mohawks, qui est en train de faire le projet de canonisation. Les ossements de la bienheureuse sont jalousement gardés par ses frères, dans leur église de Caughnawaga.

L'église de Caughnawaga est construite depuis plusieurs années. Mais l'achèvement des travaux de décoration de l'intérieur n'est pas encore terminé, les échafaudages sont même encore en place. Sa Grandeur l'archevêque d'Ottawa, Monseigneur Murray, qui a été curé pendant quinze ans à Caughnawaga, a fait des instances auprès du sous-ministre M. Duncan Scott, pour que le gouvernement lui aide financièrement les Iroquois et termine ces travaux de leur église. L'hon. Rodolphe Lemieux lui aussi, grand bienfaiteur des Amérindiens, a proposé la requête de Monseigneur Forbes. Jusqu'ici ces demandes de secours ont échoué.

Quel fut donc devant une telle situation ? Le Révérend Père C.-M. Hauser, S.J., missionnaire de Caughnawaga, de concert avec les conseillers canadiens de cette paroisse, a décidé d'inviter le public à une grande tombola dont les revenus permettront au célèbre artiste florentin Gianni Nucci de peindre la décoration de l'église. Cette tombola revêtira, comme on le pense bien, un caractère très original.

L'église du village des Indiens iroquois de Caughnawaga. C'est pour réunir la population intéressée de cette église que l'on vient d'organiser une intéressante tombola.

Les divertissements seront multiples et différents. À elle seule, la grande figuration indienne, le "paissant" sera toute une révélation pour le public. Les indiens danseront au son des tambours, leur fameuse danse de guerre et cette danse, mieux connue, dite "du soleil". On imitera aussi les cérémonies des prédécesseurs mariages et aux enterrements indiens.

Cette tombola aura lieu le 21 et le 22 septembre. Ces deux jours seront des jours de fêtes et de animations de choses intéressantes, différentes et curieuses ne devront pas manquer cette tombola.

Tous les grands bateaux fluviaux font la navette entre Lachine et Caughnawaga et quittent la 33e avenue à toutes les heures : des yachts sont aussi à la disposition du public à la 46e avenue. Comme le projet de canonisation de Catherine Tekakwitha est commencé sous la direction du Père Wynne de New York, nous sommes certains que personne ne refusera une échole pour que l'église soit magnifique, qui abritera les restes mortels d'une sainte.

The Director of Medical Services informs me he understands that some of the children attending the Caughnawaga Indian Day School report as early as 8 A.M. Dear Sir:

I have just read a letter written by Dr. Jacobs to Mr. Letourneau asking that school opens at 9 o'clock.

When I visited the Department on August 21st, I made known to you the change of hours concerning our classes, but the inclosed time tables may help you before taking a decision.

One of the principal reasons that urged each teacher to supervise her own pupils for study is that many of our advanced pupils begged us to have study from 8 o'clock to 8.30 in the classrooms to facilitate home work and memory lessons. Most homes are small, and it is utterly impossible to study -- four or five around a table with a dim light and disturbed by the cries of small children and the loud speaking of a whole family.

Although a sacrifice for us, it is well repaid because our pupils desirous of knowledge, and ambitious in their school work are grateful and profit of the great advantage of one half hour study before class. Their efforts are crowned by notable success.

During this terrible siege of sickness on the Reserve, be assured that we will watch over our pupils with vigilance and prudence and hope that no case of death will be registered. There is nothing alarming so far and all means possible have been taken to prevent contagion.

Respectfully yours,

Dear Mr. Letourneau;

(1) In view of the prevalence of contagious diseases on the reservation I wish to recommend that all the school children be vaccinated at the expense of the Department.

(2) As another useful measure for the preservation of coughs and colds among the school children, I wish to recommend that classes should start at 9 a.m. instead of 8 a.m. as it is at present for the following reasons; To start classes at 8 a.m. is really too early because very often the children awake in cold houses before the fires are made, walk bare-feet on their cold floors and often eat very little or nothing for breakfast, while the early hour often causes the children to rush with perspiration to the 8 o'clock classes. There are all conducive to colds and ill-health.

(3) Again as health officer and Indian Agent you should not allow M. Delisle to construct his stable and barn roofs in such manner that rain and snow from off them may fall upon the play-grounds of the school near the R.C. Church as he is doing at the present time. There is no doubt that this is going to cause wet playgrounds which will also be conducive to ill-health of some school children.

Yours truly

J. H. Jacobs, M.D.

My dear Sir,

Our school opened Jan. 7th with an attendance of 336 pupils. Several are sick with the grippe—others are living in Lachine.

A very great number of our pupils were out practically forty days, so you can well imagine the dreadful drawback in the schools. Nothing can remedy the situation; but with the patience and devotedness of the teachers, and the regular attendance, constant application on the part of the pupils; they can cover a good part of the year's work. Will the children co-operate and show much interest? I hope so.

Pupils of the St. Isidore Road School number twenty, in spite of bad roads and cold weather. Attendance is good. The Agent sent me a copy of the letter of Jan 10th stating that the Department extended the privilege of teaching French at St. Isidore Road School. I am surprised that permission was given upon a request made by someone who knows nothing of the situation.

The pupils of the country schools are exceedingly backwards because of their solitary lives in the woods and their genuine Indian mode of living. The parents are the real types and speak only Iroquois. Therefore progress means little to them. Out of twenty pupils, four only are French and they are in grades I and II. The pupils speak no English when they come to school and they are fifteen before they reach Grade IV. I advocate and encourage the teaching of French, because I know how useful and necessary nowadays to be a bilingualist, but I do not find the teaching of French practical at St. Isidore Road School.

Miss Snow and Miss Philipps, our two village school teachers have a class of their own this year. Both have asked for an increase of salary since October, altho they received an increase of $50. a year starting last Sept.
Again last week they renewed their demand. My reply was that I would make known their request to the Department, but personally I thought they were expecting a lot for teachers who have no diplomas, classes that require little preparation, a Principal bearing all the responsibilities and the schools a few steps from their homes. Of themselves they would never have asked such a thing, but they are being influenced.

I rely on you more than ever to co-operate with me in my duties as Principal.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Sir,

I beg to submit the following report concerning the Indian Day Schools of the Caughnawaga Reserve.

You have no doubt noticed from the different reports prepared by the different teachers for the last quarter ended March 31st last, that the average attendance was not as good as usual. There has been a great deal of sickness; there are still many cases of typhoid fever among the pupils.

The Prefect General of the Sisterhood of St. Ann's made a minute examinations in all the classes which lasted six days, and Reverend Sister Superior was happy to tell me that the results are encouraging and that the Reverend Prefect was astonished at the progress made since her last visitation a year and a half ago.

Assuredly, we have every reason to appreciate the very able and efficient manner in which Rev. Sister Superior, assisted by her excellent staff, conducts and manages the schools.

It is to me a source of pleasure to watch the growth and progress of the Indians, and to know that they are, not only being well and ably taught, but that they are at the same time, being guided and assisted to seek the higher life. My dear Sir:

The last quarterly report showed great difference in the average attendance in comparison with the preceding reports. With the exception of a few cases of truancy, all the absentees were out on account of sickness. About fifteen of our pupils were registered as typhoid fever patients either in the hospital or in their homes. Entire families are sick with the fever. The McGregor family, four children and the father are in the hospital. Annie, the oldest, 10 years old, pupil of Grade II, died this afternoon. Mary McGregor, her sister, 8 years, and Michael Curotte 12 years, a pupil of Grade IV, are on the danger list. We are praying that the contagion will not spread as in the case of small-pox, last fall. What a terrible year of sickness!

I hear that Mrs Beauvais intends retiring from school work and I would be most happy to do all within my power to assist the Department, if it so desires, to nominate a teacher that will fill the position with satisfaction. If you recollect, I have already spoken to you of one of our former teachers who has six years experience and possesses all the qualities of a good teacher.

There is a great deal of proselytizing going on here lately, and I wonder if the Department approves of that. Our poor tickled, ignorant Indians have no will of their own and it is a cause of trouble even among our school children. I congratulate you on your firmness and righteousness in not allowing our children to change school during the scholastic year.

Will the day ever come, when peace will reign in Caughnawaga.

Ma Révérende Mère,

J'ai rencontré ce matin, en compagnie du Père Hauser, Sa Grandeur Monseigneur Deschamps et nous avons étudié ensemble la question des écoles de Caughnawaga. Voici les conclusions auxquelles nous avons cru devoir nous arrêter et que je suis heureux de vous faire connaître, assuré à l'avance de votre entière coopération:

1- Nous croyons qu'il est opportun de séparer garçons et filles. En conséquence, nous suggérons que la nouvelle école (Académique) soit exclusivement réservée aux filles.

2- Pour les deux autres écoles, si l'une ne peut être réservée exclusivement aux garçons, que du moins on place ceux-ci dans des classes séparées, excepté peut-être pour la classe des bébés.

3- Pour l'enseignement du français, il semble nécessaire pour arriver à un résultat convenable qu'il se donne dès la première année. Les enfants seront ainsi en état de mieux profiter des cours qui se donnent dans les classes supérieures.

De plus, outre l'heure inscrite au programme officiel, nous croyons que, sans manquer à leur devoir envers le Département, les religieuses peuvent enseigner les matières secondaires, comme l'histoire, la géographie, l'arithmétique, le dessin, l'enseignement ménager, etc... dans les deux langues à la fois. Bien cher Monsieur,

Une absence de quelques jours m'a empêché de répondre plus tôt à votre honnête du 2 octobre dernier, relative à certaine direction donnée aux RR.SS. de Sainte-Anne qui enseignent dans les écoles de Caughnawaga.

Il s'agit sans doute de la séparation des filles et des garçons dans les classes.

Je reconnais avoir fortement conseillé aux Soeurs cette séparation dans le but de favoriser les bonnes moeurs chez les enfants. On m'avait rapporté confidentiellement certaines choses regrettables qui avaient eu lieu, non pas à l'école, où les Soeurs exercent une surveillance efficace, mais au dehors, à cause des rencontres facilitées par le fait que garçons et filles fréquentaient la même école.

Vous me faites entendre que nous aurions dû auparavant en demander l'autorisation au Département des Affaires Indiennes. Outre qu'il s'agissait d'une question qui toucha à la morale des enfants que le missionnaire a le droit de protéger, je dois avouer que je ne croyais pas que le Département s'occupât lui-même de ces détails. Et voici pourquoi je pensais ainsi :

1- On m'a affirmé que cette séparation des filles et des garçons existait déjà il y a quelques années, et que c'est le missionnaire d'alors et les institutrices qui, à cause de circonstances spéciales, peut-être le manque de local, les ont réunis, sans que le Département s'en soit préoccupé.

2- Les noms donnés aux écoles et qui subsistent encore indiquent clairement le fait de cette séparation, il y a quelques années. On dit communément en parlant d'une école "The Boys' School" et, en parlant d'une autre, "The Girls' School".

3- On m'a informé encore que la séparation des filles et des garçons ne changeant rien au nombre des classes et des institutrices, le Département n'aurait aucun déboursé supplémentaire à faire.

4- Je savais enfin que dans des écoles d'Ontario et de l'Ouest canadien, relevant de ce Département, on garde cette séparation. Y avait-il lieu de croire que la même chose ne pouvait pas être permise à Caughnawaga?

5- J'ai donc conclu qu'il s'agissait tout simplement d'un classement des élèves lequel, si je ne me trompe, a coutume d'être laissé à la Principale. Et j'ai insisté (je n'ai pas donné d'ordre, comme on semble le croire) auprès des Soeurs pour que le classement se fasse de manière à faire disparaître certains dangers pour les enfants, c'est-à-dire, en séparant les garçons et les filles.
Vous insinuez poliment que je me suis ingéré dans les affaires du Département en agissant de la sorte. Nous ne nous plaçons évidemment pas au même point de vue. Quoi qu'il en soit, si j'ai empiété sur les pouvoirs et les droits du Département, je le regrette bien, mais je n'en prie pas moins ceux qui ont la direction de ce Département de permettre cette séparation des filles et des garçons dans nos écoles catholiques de Caughnawaga. Ils contribueront ainsi au bien véritable de cette réserve.

Dans l'espoir que vous voudrez bien vous rendre à cette demande que je considère très importante, je vous prie d'agréer, cher Monsieur, mes respectueuses salutations.

Dear Sir,

In absence of a few days I have been prevented from replying sooner to your favour of the 2nd inst., concerning certain directions given to the Reverend Sisters at the time, who are teaching in the School of Baughamaga.

It is evidently about the separation of the boys from the girls in the classrooms.

I admit having thoroughly consulted the Sisters in favour of a separation, in the interest of good morals among the children. I have received confidential reports of regrettable incidents which had taken place not at the school where the Sisters are exercising efficacious discipline, but outside on account of meetings rendered easier by the fact that the boys and girls were frequenting the same school.

You have given me to understand that we should have previously asked authorization from the Department of Indian Affairs. Besides the question pertaining to the morals of the children which the Missionary has the right to protect, I must confess that I did know that the Department was paying any attention to these details. Here are the reasons why I thought so:

It was affirmed to me that such separation would prevent the boys from already being too close and that if was...
had, on account of special circumstances, may be lack of space, put them together without consideration on the part of the Department concerning the matter.

2—The names given to the schools and which are still subsisting, clearly indicate the fact of that separation a few years ago. Speaking of one school it is commonly called "the Boys' School" and speaking of the other "the Girls' School."

3—I was also informed that the separation of the girls from the boys would not change the number of classrooms nor of the teachers, and that the Department would have no supplementary expenditure to make.

4—I knew finally that in the schools of Ontario and the Canadian West, under the direction of this Department, this separation is observed. Was there any reason to believe that the same thing could not be permitted at Ongiawaga?

5—Therefore concluded that the question was simply one of classification of the pupils, which if I am not mistaken, is generally left with the Principal. And I insisted I did not give any order as you seem to believe, with the Sisters that the classification be done so as to make certain danger for the children disappear; that is to say, by separating the boys and girls.

You boldly insinuate that I meddled with the affairs of the Department by acting in this manner; I evidently do not place ourselves at the same point of view; however, if I have encroached on the prerogatives and authority of the Department, I regret it very much.
I nevertheless beg those who have the direction of this department to permit the separation of the girls from the boys in our Catholic schools of Oaquahawaga. They would thus contribute to the real welfare of the reserve.

In the hope that you will agree to this request which I consider very important, I beg you to accept, Sir, my respectful regards.

Sir,

I beg to enclose, under separate cover, the regular quarterly reports of the R. C. Schools of the Caughnawaga Indian Reserve. I trust that, upon inspection, they will prove as gratifying to you as they have to me personally.

As in the past the attendance is very good, the discipline mild but firm, the devotedness and skill of the teachers, both religious and lay, unabating; in consequence of which the progress of the children is all that can be reasonably expected.

A particular feature of this quarter's work was the display of sewing and cooking in the reception hall of the Senior School, which I took pains to visit.

Knitting, plain sewing, cutting, crocheting, and simple embroidery had been taught, as was evidenced by the mittens and stockings, children's and misses' undergarments, aprons and dresses, which were on exhibition.

The results of the cooking classes were represented by canned vegetables and fruits, by prepared meats and vegetables, cakes and candies, and a perfectly laid dinner table.

Perhaps the best effect of this new venture of the Department in favor of the Indians is the pleasure and satisfaction the pupils take in the work, and the interest and pride of the visiting parents in their children's success.

On the whole, the year has been a peaceful period of steady progress.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to inform you that I had the pleasure of attending the Closing Exercises at Senior School, Friday June 19th and I wish to inform you that I spent a most delightful afternoon.

This year the program took on a new form. Besides the traditional awarding of premiums, the school children who had been classified into six groups according to their age or ability, under the direction of their able instructor, Captain Antonio Champagne, gave a pretty display of Physical Culture Exercises. I was, indeed, much surprised to see such good work. The drills were performed with perfect harmony, great ease and grace. One could hardly believe himself in the presence of a little band of Iroquois. The parents who have never evinced much interest in school work came in larger numbers to witness the feats accomplished by their children and went away surprised, proud and happy. It can be readily seen that the Physical training that these children are receiving is greatly improving their deportment. I am sure no city school could have appeared or done better than these Indians and I was very sorry that some member of the Department was not present to see and appreciate the good work accomplished by the devoted Sisters. Each year shows a remarkable amelioration, but this year the improvement is even more noticeable.

The pupils seemed quite pleased with their premiums. They were particularly delighted with the prizes offered by Captain A. Champagne who donated $10.00 given out in the form of dollar bills or fifty cent pieces for those who showed most dexterity and perfection in the Physical Drills.

The eleven Graduates appeared well and each received the Degun Diploma for successful Typewriting. Four among them also were awarded special prizes by Mr. Cudduhy for the good work done during his recent visitation of the classrooms. The pupils spoke their parts clearly and distinctly, some in English and some in French.

I am sure we have every reason to be proud and satisfied with the work done in the Caughnawaga schools during the past year.

Your obedient servant,

The Superintendent of Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I feel it my duty to inform you that since the Concert given by the pupils of the United Church Schools on May 13th in the Senior School Auditorium, the balustrade of the staircase between the 2nd and 3rd floors needs attention. The railing itself is in a very shaky condition, four of the balusters are knocked out and several others loosened. Another mad rush, such as was witnessed at the close of that last recital, might produce a very serious catastrophe for, were the banister to give way, lives might be lost or children maimed.

We ourselves use the hall very frequently either for Physical Culture, Singing Exercises, or Sewing Lessons and, knowing the school is not too strongly built, we take the means to keep it in good condition. On this account, as well as for obtaining better discipline, thereby rendering supervision easier, we compel our boys to file from one part of the building to another with arms folded. Our girls also are not allowed to cling to the balustrade, hence we feel we are not responsible in any way for the present condition of the staircase, nor for whatever accident might occur in the future. Nor do we blame Mr. Robert who found himself more than sufficiently occupied in guarding the entrance door and warding off intruders from other parts of the building.

The Auditorium was not left in a very clean condition. The floor was
not only strewn with crushed paper bags, but even gum adhered to the floor. In the sweepings were found matches and cigarette stubs. The stage table was left minus a leg. During the latter part of the Recital, those sitting in the rear seats took the liberty of standing upon the chairs.

I understand that Constable Jocks and Mr. Joe Jacobs took charge of the Auditorium during the evening, and though I believe they tried to do their duty, and probably did much to preserve order by their presence, they certainly lack that sense of foresight and minuteness with regard to details, so necessary when one desires to keep a building and its equipment in good shape.

We trust we shall be spared further annoyance of this kind as we feel that justice is not being rendered to us when we do our utmost to preserve intact all that the Government has placed at our disposal.

Hoping the above remarks will be taken into consideration,

My dear Mr. Ferrier,

At the close of the Scholastic Year 1931-32 I come to thank you for the help rendered by the Department in so many ways thus enabling us to make our year in the classroom a successful one.

As you are aware, our Distribution of Premiums took place on June 20th. The Sisters were quite disappointed that office duties kept you away. We had hoped to the last minute that a message would reach us announcing your arrival in Montreal. As that pleasure was denied us, we trust that next June, when we expect to turn out a very nice and large Graduating Class, nothing will prevent you from honoring us with your presence. We had a larger number of guests than in the past. Formerly, school gatherings did not appeal to the people here, but gradually parents are becoming more interested in their children's success and such encouragement on their part makes our work easier. Four teachers from England attended our Closing Exercises, teachers whom the Montreal Catholic School Board had received last September for a year's experience across the ocean in exchange for four members of their own staff.

It was quite a revelation to them to learn that little Indians could be brought to do as well as white children. They were generous with their praises regarding the children's bearing, their perfect discipline throughout the entertainment, their good singing, and the precision and
grace with which they went through the Physical Culture performance.

Such applause from outsiders means much to us for we desire our Indian children to be looked upon with a friendly eye. In fact, we have every reason to be satisfied with our little band. Their deportment in the classroom, in general, has been very good, and when we take into consideration the latitude allowed these children in the homes, the "Very Good" gives way to "Excellent". The attendance also was far better this winter and the teachers noted with pleasure a vast improvement in the classwork. If we are to judge from the smiling face as each child received the rewards so generously donated by the Department, the pupils left us happy and contented. May September bring them back to us as light-hearted and as willing to continue their march in the path of knowledge.

With regard to the Bush School and that of St. Isidore Road, good work is being done even if not as apparent as elsewhere for one must bear in mind that these children are deprived of many of the advantages of which the village schools boast.

Before closing, I wish to add a word with reference to your inquiry about "Maxim's Arithmetic Cards" published by J.L. Hammett & Co. of Boston. We still use these cards in our Junior Classes and find them indispensable if one's aim is to develop accuracy; hence we strongly recommend their use to those who would render their pupils apt and quick at numbers.

This innovation was introduced for the first time last year, in December and May, and not for years past as your letter seems to imply. In December, much of the woodwork was scratched on account of the enormous tree brought up the staircase. Of the damage done in May, you are already aware.

Will you kindly allow me to make a suggestion, dear Mr. Phelan? Why not advise Miss Daly to use the Councillors' Hall which has not only a seating capacity of about two hundred, but also a stage with anterooms adjoining. Would not that be large enough for the Xmas tree needs of the forty pupils? Perhaps the Night School Equipment was formerly an incumbrance to Social Gatherings in this hall, but hindrances of the kind no longer exist. The room may not be as pretty as the Senior School Hall, but there, greater freedom may be enjoyed without fear of ruining any property and at the same time, it will allow one and all to have the "right-at-home" spirit which should pervade every Christmas Festival.

Dear Mr. Phelan, I have frankly laid forth my views on the matter, and now will leave you to do what you judge best.

Trusting you will do your utmost to favor my standpoint of the subject, I enclose kindest regards.

Yours sincerely,

Sir,

With regard to the work carried on by the Roman Catholic Schools of the Caughnawaga Reserve, I beg to say that entire satisfaction is being given in every line. All the members of the teaching staff are doing splendid work, whether it be in the moral, intellectual, or physical development of their Indian charges.

I wish to praise especially the discipline which abounds in the classroom and the interest each Sister takes in the protection of the government property. The attractive and neat appearance of the classrooms suffices to indicate that every effort is made to render school life as pleasant as possible for the Indians.

The Teachers find that the daily lunch and Cod Liver Oil served during school hours robs the School Curriculum of very valuable time, but, on the other hand, they are glad to have food to give to many whose restlessness and languor in the classroom were due to want of nourishment.

As you are always aware, certain troublesome Indians would like to have their own in charge of some of the classes, but I believe the wisest plan for the Department to follow is to leave the entire school in the Sisters' care as long as they are able to control the larger boys as ably as they do at the present hour.

Trusting you will be as satisfied with the work accomplished in the Roman Catholic Schools of Caughnawaga as I am myself, I remain,

Your obedient servant,

I beg to submit to your consideration the case of an indian schoolchild by the name of Angus Deerhouse, attending the Eastern school at Caughnawaga. This boy is the son of Mitchell Deerhouse of this Reserve.

Angus was attending school very irregularly until lately when he was compelled to be regular through the action of the truant officer. This boy is setting a very bad example to the other pupils of his class and of the entire school, as he insults his teacher every day and openly challenges the Sister. Memorandum:

Mr. Sutherland,

When I visited the Caughnawaga R. C. Indian Day School on the 4th instant, Reverend Sister Mary Cleophas, the Principal, suggested the employment of an additional teacher.

As you are aware, classes are conducted in the school at the present time to Grade VIII, which is the highest grade in the elementary schools in the Province of Quebec.

If an additional Sister was engaged, Grade IX could be taught. This would permit keeping the girls in school until sixteen years of age. Many of them now complete their school course at fifteen, when they are too young to obtain work and, for moral reasons, the Reverend Sister considers that it would be very advisable to start the Grade IX work. In addition to the academic training, this would give another year for the girls to take advantage of the domestic science and sewing classes which the Reverend Sisters conduct.

A salary of $800 a year would be required and there is accommodation in the Senior School for the extra room.

I consider that it would be in the best interests of the children to adopt the Reverend Sister Superior's suggestion and I would strongly recommend that she be authorized to secure the services of another Sister who is a qualified teacher and begin Grade IX work in the Caughnawaga Senior School on September 1st, 1935.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th instant enclosing a communication received at Ottawa from Mrs. Josephine Diabo of this Reserve with reference to her daughter Ida Morris attending the Senior School.

In reply, I beg to transmit you the following report of Rev. Sister Mary Cleophas, Principal, regarding Ida's behaviour and character. According to the Principal, the girl has since the beginning of the school year been very stubborn and impudent for her teacher at school. A few days ago, Ida squarely refused to follow the instructions of her teacher, who unable to have the girl obey, sent for the Principal. The Principal was also unable to get anything from the little girl who resisted the Sister and insulted her in front of the whole class, for almost half an hour, whereupon, the Truant Officer, J.K. Jocks was called and was also boldly answered by Ida who stated to have been told by her mother that she was not obliged to follow the instructions given at school nor had the Truant Officer anything to do with her. As all had been tried unsuccessfully, the Principal sent the girl home, in order to give an example to the other children and to maintain the authority at school.

The mother and the girl called at this office and I may say that Josephine seems to be the one responsible for her daughter's misbehaviour, as she kept on saying that the Sisters have "no right to make the children do what they do not want to nor to punish them, in any way."

Conference On Canadian Poetry

That Canadian poets are neglected by their own is a complaint frequently heard; and the blame is laid, in part, on the schools that do not foster the taste and develop the knowledge in the growing boy and girl.

That a real beginning had been made was strikingly evident at the Third Annual Conference in January of the Course for Teachers in Service at the Institute of Pedagogy of the University of Montreal.

A bright group of boys and girls of the Seventh Grade from the Caughnawaga Government Schools demonstrated how clearly they comprehended and artistically appreciated that haunting descriptive lyric of Archibald Lampman, "Morning on the Lievre." To these children of forest and stream abroad in a canoe. Nature speaks with a voice and suggests a loveliness which we urbanites often fail to catch and to see.

The young lads of the Seventh Grade had studied Marjorie Pickthall's ecstatic poem "Père Lalemant." Only children as well versed in the practice of their Faith as these could have under the careful tutelage of the brother of Père Lalemant, S.J., one of our own Canadian martyrs, could have found so much of interest and things to say of Marjorie Pickthall's long life, "I lift the Lord on high!" "The blood of the martyrs is, truly, the seed of Christians."

Miss Pauline Jocks, dressed in the dainty costume of an Indian maiden, closed the highly original hour with a piano rendering of Pauline Johnson's "The Song My Paddie Sings," averring as her reason for donning the dress that Pauline Johnson herself wore her recitals from ocean to ocean in America and in England, where she was acclaimed by royalty even, usually appeared in the attire of her race.

This Canadian program was made possible by the fact that the Department of Indian Affairs of the Canadian government has adopted for their Caughnawaga Schools the newly published Canadian Catholic CORONA Readers, which abound in Canadian narratives and Canadian events.

The hour was given under the direction of the Sisters of St. Anne of Lachine, who have been in charge of these Caughnawaga schools for the past twenty years.

MEMORANDUM:

DR. MCGILL.

I visited the Caughnawaga Reserve on June 5th and 6th and inspected all the classrooms.

With special regard to the Caughnawaga R. C. Day School, we have been employing, for some years, Capt. Champagne as physical training instructor, at a salary of $400 a year. I saw an exhibition of the physical culture work under the direction of Capt. Champagne and it could not be considered very satisfactory. On enquiring from the Principal, I found that Capt. Champagne teaches physical culture at several schools in Montreal and, as a result, devotes only a comparatively short time to the work at the Caughnawaga School.

There are approximately 350 children enrolled at this school and, of these, about 30 are backward. This is not a large proportion, as statistics show that in white schools approximately 10% of the children are in the same category.

The Sister Superior considers that if they had an extra teaching sister on the staff they could provide special attention for these 30 backward children. Such a plan would assist the children and, at the same time, help the classes, as these backward children are distributed in the various rooms and have a tendency to retard the work. This extra teacher would also be prepared to handle the physical drill.

I would, therefore, recommend that the Department dispense with Capt. Champagne's services and appoint a new teaching sister at the usual salary of $750. This would mean a net increase of $350, but as you will note from what I have said above, there would be many advantages to compensate for the extra cost.

Dear Sir:

I was greatly surprised to receive a letter from Mr. Brisebois, your agent at Caughnawaga, informing me that my services would be no longer required, and that my appointment as Physical Training Instructor would not be continued from September onward.

This year, notwithstanding my best efforts I have not reached the standard of former years. I attribute this to lower mental and physical capacities of some of the pupils. Caughnawaga, Que., June 15, 1923.

The close of the present school year will mark the end of my term of office as local Superior and Superintendent of the Schools in Caughnawaga. Before leaving, I feel it my duty to thank you for your very great kindness and consideration as well as for the keen interest you have shown in my work. This made the task less strenuous than it might otherwise have been.

When in September 1917 I came here, the conditions were anything but hopeful. But I kept before my mind the suggestion you made at the time in an official communication to Mother Mary Melanie, the Superior General, regarding the possibility that I take up my duties in a conciliatory spirit. Now that six years have elapsed, I can safely assert that I tried to prove true to my promise, and avoided all unpleasant relations with the people. I labored for the uplifting of the race, and the improvement of the Schools, giving the best of my years of experience to the work of teaching the Indian children.

I feel that little would have been accomplished had I not met with the courtesy, generosity and support of the Officials of the different branches of the Department, and to each and every one of these I wish to express my sincere gratitude.

Would you be good enough to extend to them all, to Mr. McKenzie, Mr. McLean, Mr. Chene, Mr. Ferrier, Mr. Sutherland, Mr. Williams, with whom I have had special relations, the assurance of my deep appreciation.

I have been officially appointed Provincial Superior of our British Columbia Province, and will have under my jurisdiction the Indian Schools of Ramahps, St. Mary's and Kuper Island. I need hardly tell you that I shall keep a very kindly eye on these houses in view of the fact of my relations with the Department here.

I will leave for British Columbia on July 8th, in all probability and will reside in our Provincial house in Victoria, Vancouver Island.

Thanking you once again, and assuring you that the interests of the Indian Schools in the West will be the object of my constant care,

I am, dear Mr. Scott,

Dear Sister Cleophas:

I understand that a number of white children whose parents live on the Caughnawaga reserve are at this date, and have been for some time, enrolled at the R. C. schools on the reserve. It is unnecessary to point out to you that the Government is under no obligation whatever to provide instruction for these children.

I have been informed that it is the intention of the Department to ask the parents of these children to leave the reserve at an early date and a notice to this effect will reach these white residents of the reserve in the course of a few days. A list of these residents will be submitted to you by Mr. Brisebois. I am of the opinion that all white children whose parents have been asked to leave the reserve should be excluded from your schools. It is highly desirable that your notice to these children to leave the school should reach the children and, through them, the parents at the same time that they receive the departmental notice to remove from the reserve. Dear Sister Cleophas:

The officials of the Welfare and Training Division of this Branch inform me that you are, in conformity with the rules of your Order, resigning from the principalship of the Caughnawaga Indian day school at the end of the present academic year.

I am anxious at this time to express to you, on behalf of the officials of this Branch, our sincere appreciation of the work you have undertaken and accomplished at the Caughnawaga school during the period of your principalship. I have had an opportunity from time to time to inspect the handwoven ties, scarfs and bags produced at your school by the senior girls. The fine workmanship displayed in the production of these articles reflects, in my judgment, great credit, not only on the pupils but on those responsible for their instruction.

I have been informed that you have completed a period of fifty years of educational effort. It is difficult to overstate or overemphasize the unselfish contribution you have made in this period of time. It must be a source of great satisfaction to you to realize that this contribution has been constructive and helpful though perhaps not always appreciated by the people amongst whom you have laboured.

With very best wishes for the future, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

My dear Sister Cleophas:

The officials of the Welfare and Training Division of the Indian Affairs Branch are anxious that I should convey to you at this time our sincere thanks for the cooperation extended to us during the period of your principalship at the Caughnawaga Indian Day School.

We shall not easily forget your abiding interest in the welfare and progress of the Indian pupils committed to your care. We remember particularly your enthusiastic and successful attempts to organize and promote worthwhile handicraft projects at your school in recent years and the worth of these to the senior girls who took advantage of them.

We regret more than we can easily express in words your departure from the Caughnawaga school, your devotion to duty, your unfailing courtesy at all times and your contribution to the cause of human betterment on the reserve. These, we shall always remember with gratitude. There are few people, even in the sphere of missionary effort, who have succeeded in establishing such a record of faithful and unselfish service.

May we, in thanking you for your contribution, express the hope that the years that may lie ahead of us may bring to you the best that life itself has to offer.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supv. of Welfare and Training.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

With the new school term close at hand, school problems arise also—

1.—I have already spoken to you of the great number of absentees at our schools. We will most likely face the same difficulties this coming year, if more drastic measures are not taken to get our pupils at school. I mean both parents and children must pay the penalty or no change will result, I am very sure.

Could not the Agent inflict a fine penalty on stubborn absentees' parents or on pupils leaving before their sixteenth year? There must be a drastic movement made at the school opening or our past difficulties will continue and even increase. We have suffered much in the past, but I trust that efficient discipline will afford us as regards regular school attendance. All, you understand, must be made to adhere to school regulations with no mercy whatever—reasons for leaving at fifteen because of size, help needed by parents, etc., etc., should not be tolerated but I must be strictly upheld by the Agent and the Truant Officer whom parents and children will fear.

I am confident, dear Mr. Phelan, that you will help us as school work would benefit by regular attendance.

2.—Has any decision been reached as to the Woodwork? Shall we close this department this fall? The Jesuits as I said before, have no Brother to replace Brother Gauthier.

3.—Will the Department afford grants to our five June Graduates:
