Dear Mr. Raymond:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of September 4, written by you on behalf of a number of white residents of the Caughnawaga Indian Reserve, who are anxious to have their children attend the Indian day school on the reserve. It is noted that these parents are prepared to pay a nominal fee of $1.00 a month per child for the instruction of their children.

You are probably aware that the accommodation at the Caughnawaga schools is somewhat limited. This is particularly true of the larger schools in the village, where the accommodation at present is not sufficient to provide vocational instruction for a number of the senior pupils and a number of girls who have already completed the regular school course. You may be interested to learn that we have at the moment under consideration a request for the construction of an additional room suitable for instruction in manual training, home economics, etc. In view of this condition, the Department is of the opinion that it would be very unwise to enroll white pupils at the larger schools. As the Government's building program, other than buildings necessary for our war effort, has been suspended, we are convinced that in the days immediately ahead no additional space will be required to provide instruction for the Indian pupils on the reserve. A temporary arrangement, therefore, whereby instruction might be provided for certain white pupils, would in our judgment be scarcely fair to the teachers in charge of our schools or to the white pupils themselves.

Yours sincerely,

W. J. F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.

Maxime Raymond, Esq., M.P.,
Montreal, Que.
Dear Sir:

I have been requested by Mrs. Thomas Lazare of this Reserve to submit you the case of her grandchild, Johny Cowan, aged seven, who is of school age but who cannot attend the local schools as he has the status of white.

Mr. James Cowan is enlisted in the Active Service and is presently in England. He married Mrs. Lazare's daughter, Josephine, who lives with her on the Reserve together with her two children, one is four and the other seven.

Previous to her marriage Josephine was an Indian. When she married she lived at Lachine with her husband who up to the time of his enlistment was a member of the R.C.M.P., but after her husband left for overseas she came and resided on the Reserve with her mother and her father-in-law, Thomas Lazare, who is an invalid.

Mr. Lazare claims that as they are in destitute circumstances they are most anxious for Mrs. Cowans to remain with them on the Reserve as if she goes and lives elsewhere they will be compelled to apply for relief. At the present time Mrs. Cowans lives with them rent free and in return is supporting them. However if her son cannot attend school she will have to move out of the Reserve. As a matter of fact it is stated that she looked for a house in Montreal, Lachine and other places but could not find a suitable house except for prices ranging between $40.00 and $60.00 per month, which rentals she is unable to afford.

Will you kindly let me know if due to the fact that Josephine, who was a Band member before her marriage, is married with an Active Service man who is supporting her parents and who is unable to find adequate lodgings could be given permission to send her son to School. It may be that due to the conditions above described the Department could do something in this particular case.

Yours very truly,

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Your letter of July last regarding the finding of a practical man to continue the wood work in the schools of Caughnawaga must have been mislaid without being read. I know that I received the proposed course of study, which I read with considerable interest. I find it very practical and systematic and well calculated to give the boys a good initiation into elementary shop work.

Your letter of September 5th came to my address while I was in Quebec. Since my return, I have tried without success to find the man you want. The teachers who do this work in my inspectorate are all full time teachers in the various schools of the Montreal Catholic School Commission.

Your request does not necessarily call for a teacher, but rather for a "practical man". However, as you know, the men who answer to this description are nearly all engaged in war industries.

I have a suggestion to make, which I want you to know is made without any motive of personal interest. If you have not found any one for the work, I think that my father would be able to do it. Naturally, he is not a young man. He retired from the Montreal Railways Company in 1935. He had been for many years superintendent of construction and maintenance in the power department of that company. He is not a carpenter by trade, but an electrician and all-round mechanic. At present, he occupies his leisure by making and repairing fishing-rods. His hobby brings him a small profit.

Dear Sir:

As you are aware the R.C.Schools have reopened on the 15th instant instead of on the 1st of next month.

We have several boys and girls who are in School age who are at present employed at the Empire Food Co., at Ste-Martine, Que., about 13 miles from the Reserve. Others are also employed at the Canadian Canners at St.Isidore, Que., which is also near the Reserve.

May I say that there is a serious shortage of labour and that these employers had to employ children under 16 in order to prevent any waste of fruits and vegetables, which accounts for the fact that many indian children have gone to work until the last of October.

However the Rev.Sister Superior seems to be opposed to their absence from School and has asked the Constable to go to the above mentioned places in order that the children in school age be dismissed from work. The Constable was instructed not to do anything before being advised by you.

May I say that I would favour, if agreeable to you, that these children be permitted to continue working up to the first of next month, owing to the present condition, and moreover if similar condition exists next year, the teachers should be instructed not to reopen the Schools before the last of October as it is of the utmost importance that everything be done to prevent any wastage. An early reply would be much appreciated.

Yours very truly,

Re: School Attendance

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 17th instant, in which you intimate that several boys and girls of school age are at present employed with the Empire Food Company; that a number of others are employed at the Canadian Canners at St. Isidore, Que., and that it is not at all likely that these pupils will report at school until on or about October 1.

In view of the acute labour shortage existing throughout the country and in view of the concessions already made by provincial departments of education, the Department is of the opinion that these pupils should be permitted to continue at the work in which they are now engaged until October 1. This decision applies particularly to senior pupils. You should inform the Principal of the school that these are critical times in which we are living and that this nation, together with other nations, is fighting for its very existence. You should point out to her, also, that Section 10 (subsection 5, paragraph 'c') of the Indian Act reads:

"No parent or other person shall be liable to such penalties if such child has been excused in writing by the Indian agent or teacher for temporary absence to assist in husbandry or urgent and necessary household duties".

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

We acknowledge receipt of your letter dated March 31st with reference to the equipment for the Domestic Science Room here.

I am sorry to note that you seem to find that we have been extravagant in the purchase of the necessary articles. May I assure you, Mr. Phelan, that I have bought only those articles which were approved on the submitted list and even at that, when I found prices unreasonable, I did not purchase the article at all, e.g. the kitchen cabinet which would have cost at least $150.00. The counters were also very high so I purchased the lumber and Mr. Wescott and his men built them up for us at about one-third the quoted price.

I have spent long days scouting the city for advantageous prices on serviceable equipment. I admit that equipping a kitchen for the use of twelve (12) girls requires the purchase of many pots and pans, cutlery etc. I, myself, had no idea that the project would cost as much as it did for I would not have proposed it at this critical time. However, I am encouraged by the thought that this project will be a means of keeping our young girls interested in schoolwork and will keep them from much moral danger outside. Furthermore, every bit of the equipment purchased, will be transferrable to new quarters if ever a new school is built for the Caughnawaga children.

Many of our girls of fourteen and fifteen have left school for work. We have tried every expedient to get them back to class but uselessly. The reopening of the Domestic Science Room is my only hope now. Some of these
Girls are working in places where they are very exposed morally and physically. They are not yet strong enough to withstand the fatigue caused by the work assigned them. Most of the mothers will not listen to reason being tempted by the few extra dollars coming into the house. It is sad to have to stand by and see our nice young girls being destroyed. No matter what it will cost me, I am decided to try to remedy the situation here in Caughnawaga, if possible. We cannot count on Mr. Jocks to help us to keep our pupils in school. People are not afraid of him and they are very prone to speak about his public scandalous conduct. As a help, would you write me a strong letter to the effect that pupils who are not fifteen may not go to work so that I may use it when needed. To give it still more value, probably Mr. Brisebois could read it to the pupils in school.

You may be interested to know that the Woodwork Department has kept about 90% of our big boys in school while the girls registration has dwindled from 19 in October to 5 in March. If you have any other suggestion, I would be very grateful for it.

As soon as all the work in the Domestic Science and the Woodwork rooms is completed, I hope to arrange for a special demonstration and I trust that either you or Mr. Hoey will be able to be present. I am ready to cooperate with you in every respect.

Respectfully yours,

SISTERS OF SAINT ANN

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent, Caughnawaga, Que.

As you are aware, the compulsory age for attendance of Indian children at Indian day schools on a reserve is 7 to 16 years. It has been brought to our attention that many of the girls of 14 and 15 years of age on the Caughnawaga Reserve who should be attending school have quit in order to obtain work.

It would be appreciated if you would point out to both parents and children that the Department expects the girls to take advantage of the educational facilities provided for them at the Caughnawaga schools. Children who leave school as young as those just mentioned will not likely return to school and, therefore, will not have the training which they will require in after years. Consequently the Department feels that their education should not be neglected simply for a temporary advantage.

As you are aware, the Department has re-established the domestic science room at the Caughnawaga R.C. School and, as a result, excellent training can be given to the girls in this class of work in addition to their academic work.

I trust that your interest in this matter will have the effect of keeping the teen-age girls in school.

The Commissioner, The Royal Canadian Mounted Police, Ottawa

In confirmation of telephone conversation with Superintendent Darlin I have to advise you that this Branch was informed this morning by Sister Mary George, Principal of the Caughnawaga Indian Roman Catholic School, that the school known as the Kateri Indian Day School in the village of Caughnawaga was broken into and a considerable amount of supplies and equipment stolen.

I shall be obliged if you will please have this matter thoroughly investigated and advise me further in connection therewith in due course.

Director.
Ottawa,
June 4, 1943.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

As requested, I visited the Caughnawaga Reserve in connection with the report we had received regarding the robbery at the Kateri School.

I found that, acting on the request of Dr. McGill, the R.C.M.P. had visited the school on the afternoon of Wednesday, June 2, and made a very exhaustive examination of the building, especially the domestic science room. I also understand they interviewed one or two people but no information was available regarding any information they obtained from them.

It appears that when the Sisters went to the school on the morning of May 31 they found some small branches of trees and a number of burnt matches in several of the rooms. They reported the incident to the Indian office. However, Agent Brisebois was absent on duty at the Oka Reserve.

On Wednesday morning when they reached the school it was found that approximately $150.00 worth of equipment had been taken from the domestic science room. This included electric toaster, iron, dishes, cutlery, scissors, thread etc. Investigation also showed that whoever entered the school had visited a number of the classrooms and stolen fountain pens, chalk and even a map of North America and burnt matches were strewn around the place. In addition, the handles on the taps of the water system leading to the boiler had been removed. Further investigation showed that the burglars had entered the building by the fire escape and had gained admittance by removing a pane of glass from the door at the top of the fire escape. It was informed by the Rev. Sister that the police had found some minor clues and they also took several impressions in an endeavour to obtain fingerprints.

The Rev. Sister advised me that there had been several minor robberies throughout the village in the last few months.

I understand that our Branch has been negotiating with the R.C.M.P. with a view to placing one or more officers on the reserve. I was informed that Mrs. Paul Paul has a very nice residence that is situated a short distance from the former Agency office. Mrs. Paul intends to reside with her married daughter on another part of the reserve and it is quite possible that her own residence could be secured as a residence for the R.C.M.P.
From reports received it is evident that the present constable has survived his usefulness and it also appears very necessary that when a community as large as Caughnawaga Village is situated close to the largest city in Canada adequate police protection should be provided.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dr. Harold W. McGill, Director, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

I have to refer to your letter of the 7th instant dealing with the recent robbery at the Caughnawaga School and conditions on the Reserve and in this connection to say that the R.C.M.Police are actually investigating these thefts and have strong suspicions on three young Indians. I understand warrants will be taken out against these parties.

With regard to the house of Mrs. Paul Paul as a suitable residence for the Royal Canadian Mounted Police officer, I may say that this woman was interviewed. On that occasion she stated that her house was not for rent, but however if the Department wants that house she would rent for a period not exceeding five years at an annual rental of $500.00. Moreover if improvements are made she does not want to have same deducted from her rent. There is no water in that house but there is a well on the property.

This house is an old stone house similar to the former Agency's building but in very good order. However the rental asked is considered exorbitant.

I am trying to find other places which would be suitable but apparently the Indian owners seem to be afraid to rent to an R.C.M.Police as they have the wrong idea that they would be treated severely and are apparently afraid to be blamed by other Indians for the coming of Mounted Police, if they rent their properties.

It is my opinion that if an unmarried R.C.M.Police officer could be appointed for six months or a year, who could reside at the house used as Agency's office, it would convince the property owners that the Mounted Police officers are not to persecute them...but
but to protect the population. It is believed that it would then be possible to find quarters for a married man.

(Frs. Brisebois)

To this she replied that she suspected the sister of Andrew, June DeLisle age 14. She suspected her, because she did not like the manner in which she carried herself in school. She also suspected Joseph Diabo, whose character is not of the best on the Reserve.

6. Superior George was asked if she had reported the matter to the local Sp/Cst. Jocks, to which she replied, that she had not, as it was useless to report anything to him as he protected those who did wrong, instead of bringing them to Justice.

7. Leaving the school, we proceeded to interview Jos. DeLisle, father of Andrew and June DeLisle. He was questioned about the actions of his two children on the night of the theft, he stated that both had been home all evening, the son having gone to bed around 8.30 P.M. and June helped her mother to paint the floors and when he arrived around 10 P.M. they were both in bed. When the father was question neither one of the children were present. I then went to the home of the two children, were both were questioned separately. Andrew stated that on the evening of the 31st, after church he was playing tag, with some other children in the school yard, that he and the others were running up the fire escape, but that neither he nor the other children entered the school by that door.

P.T.C.

C.C. of C. AMENDED TO: Alleged Breaking & Entering
Kateri Indian Day School,
Caughnawaga, Que.

June 5th 1943

On above date accompanied by Cst. Plouffe, I proceeded to Caughnawaga and interviewed Mr. Laplante, Asst. Indian Agent, in the absence of Mr. Brisebois the Indian Agent. Mr. Laplante informed me that the above school had been broken into and several articles from the Domestic Science Room had been stolen. The articles stolen were the property of the Dept. of Indian Affairs. I was instructed to interview the Sister Superior for further information.

Sister Superior George, of the Congregation of Ste. Anne, was interviewed, and she stated, "that on the A.M. of May 28th, it was reported to her by another Nun, that the fire escape door on the second floor of the school house, had been forced and that the desks in the class rooms, had been rearranged but they could not find anything missing, with the exception of a few red marking pencils. On the A.M. of the 30th ult., they again found that the same fire escape door had again been forced, they again investigated and found nothing missing. On the morning of the 1st inst., this same door was again forced and opened and after investigating they found that a set of Rogers cutlery "Silverware" and excessories, 1 Electric Toaster, 1 Electric Iron and a few other kitchen utensils were missing from the Domestic Science Room, which is situated in the basement of the Kateri School. They also found on this occasion a black wallet, belonging to one of the pupils, namely Andrew Delisle, this wallet was found in between the inner and outer door leading to the fire escape, also the desks in the classrooms were opened and about $3.00 in cash, which was in a box taken out. Sister George immediately notified the Indian agent, but in his absence the information was given to Mr. Laplante the Asst., She also called the Dept., at Ottawa and notified them. On the A.M. of the 2nd inst., the same fire escape door was found opened, this time the culprits, took out the putty around a small glass, took the glass out and unhooked the door, after investigating they found that the person or persons had visited the Domestic Science Room, having entered same by taking the lock off the door, incidently the Sister informed me that this door was not locked, and there was no reason why the lock was taken off, on entering the room they found burnt matches all over the floor and that a 16 piece service "Dinner" set, was missing from the cabinet and several other pieces of kitchen utensils. On the floor in front the cabinet they found that the floor was covered with clipped paper "excelsior" packing. I was informed that this paper was the paper which packed the dishes in when they received them, that same had been stored in the furnace room in boxes and that the boxes were also missing. After the theft the culprits left by the basement door."

We proceeded to the school in question and examined the premises, the small glass taken out of the door.

With reference to the above and further to my P.C.R. of the 22nd inst., I beg to report that on the 25th inst., John CROTE and Gilbert LEBORGNE the two accused in this case, appeared before Judge C.E. Guerin for sentence, both accused were released on Parole and instructed to report back before the Judge on October 15th 1943, they were also instructed by the presiding Judge to return the articles which had not been recovered.

The presiding Judge took for granted that the two accused were only 17 years of age and that they were Indians, thus the reason of not giving them a jail sentence.

On the afternoon of the 25th inst., I proceeded to Caughnawage, P.Q., to recover the articles which were still missing, but on my arrival at that point I was informed that these two young men had not returned home. On the evening of the same date I again returned to the Reserve and there contacted the two young men and the following articles were returned to me:- 1 Electric Toaster "Hotpoint", 1 Food Chopper, 1 Bread Knife, 10 Paring Knives, 2 sets of Measuring Spoons and 1 Screw Driver, these articles were brought to H.Q., and placed in the Bond with the other articles which were recovered on the 21st inst.

At the present time most of the articles have been recovered, there only remains a few smaller pieces and these two young men do not know what they did with them, as to the money ($3.00) mentioned in paragraph two (2) of my P.C.R. of the 5th inst., both of them deny taking same.

1. With reference to the above and your instructions of the 18th inst., on my P.C.R. of the 5th inst., I beg to report that on this date, accompanied by S/Cst. Lafrenne, I proceeded to Caughnawaga, P.Q., to pick up one of the suspects John LaTour and bring him to Montreal H.Q., for questioning in connection with this B. & E., I was unable to find him as he had left the reserve earlier that date and had gone into town, at his home I was unable to find out where he had gone.

2. Whilst at the Reserve I made inquiries in connection with the School Janitor Albini Robert, I was informed that he had arrived in Caughnawaga about 18 years ago from St. Boniface, Man., that at one time he was a member of some Brothers Congregation, that he was worth around $70,000.00, owning quite a bit of property out West and in vicinity of Montreal and District. I was also informed that this person is somewhat of a miser and deals quite a bit with the Indians on the Reserve, by buying things from them and selling them to others at a profit, he also finances the Indians there at a profit. I was speaking to Sister Superior George about this person and she informed me that he had received his notice, that his term of engagement with the Dept., terminated in July of this year and that she hoped that he would not be reengaged, seeing the business he was carrying on with the Indians.

19-6-43

3. On this date I happened to go to the Que. Prov. Police H.Q., and there I was informed by Det. A. Oglier, that he was working on a B. & E. case at the Kanawaki Golf Club, which is located on the Reserve and that he suspected the same persons as I did in the School Affair. Seeing this it was decided to work together on the two B. & E. This same day I again proceeded to Caughnawaga and there questioned John LaTour, he denied having anything to do with either B. & E., we questioned several others namely Joseph Blain, William Lahache and Mrs. Angus Lahache but none of these persons knew anything about the matter.

4. The assistance of S/Cst. Jocks was then asked, he could not throw any light on the matter, but informed us that a party by the name of John Currie was going around the Reserve armed with a revolver, this party was located at the Convent in the act of bargaining with the Janitor Albini Robert to buy the revolver which was in his possession. Currie was immediately placed under arrest by Det. Oglier, C.P.P., for being in possession of a firearm and brought back to the City and placed in the C.P. Police cells, pending his arraignment on the 21st inst. It was then decided to leave this man in the cells over the week-end before questioning him any further. As to the revolver he claims that he had received it from an unknown man, who asked him to sell it for him, but it was ascertained from S/Cst. Jocks, that this revolver had been stolen out of the house of a party named Beauvais.

P.T.O.
5. On the A.M. on this date I proceeded to the H.Q. of the Q.P. Police and there questioned John CUROTTE in the presence of Det. Ogger, he admitted having entered the Golf Club on two occasions, namely the night of June 17th and 18th 1943 and had stolen several tools, etc., he also admitted to me that he had entered the Kateri School House on the night of June 1st - 2nd 1943, but that he had only gone in there after some other persons had broken into the place, he told me that he had stolen several small articles, namely 2 Maps, 1 Fountain Pen, Pencils, 6 Shirts, 1 Punch, 1 Mackinaw, 1 Screwdriver, 1 piece of Sealing Wax, 4 prs. Scissors, Crochet Needles, 1 Can Opener and 1 set of measuring spoons, he claimed that he had all these articles at home in his room, with the exception of 2 shirts which he had given away to persons he did not know and that the measuring spoons he had given them to Mrs. Alex RICE.

6. During the questioning he admitted having broken into the Golf Club with Gilbert LEBORGNE, but he denied that this party accompanied him when he entered the School House. He denied having stolen the Dinner Set, the Silverware and other articles previously mentioned in my report of the 5th inst.

7. Proceeding to Caughnawaga, P.Q. with Dets. Ogger and Jean Page, we picked up Gilbert LEBORGNE at his home, he admitted having entered the Golf Club with John CUROTTE, but denied having anything to do with the School Theft. We then proceeded to the home of John CUROTTE and there found in his room on the second floor the tools stolen from the Golf Club also the articles which he claimed that he had stolen from the School with the exception of 1 Screw Driver, 4 prs Scissors and Crochet Needles.

8. We then went to the home of Mrs. Alex RICE and there she gave me the measuring spoons which CUROTTE had given her, before leaving her I questioned this person, whether she had bought any articles from this party, she claimed that she had bought a Dinner Set for 8 persons, 1 Set of Rogers Silverware 12 pieces, 2 Berry Spoons, 7 Crochet Needles and 3 pkgs. Embroidery Needles, these articles were handed over to me and she claimed that she bought nothing else. Mrs. Rice paid $5.00 for the dishes and $9.00 for the Silverware. Before leaving this person she informed me that the party across the street had also bought some dishes.

9. Proceeding across the street I questioned Mrs. Annie MONTGOMERY (widow) she claimed that she did not understand me, I then had Gilbert LEBORGNE enter to interpretate for me, finally she pointed to a corner in the kitchen and in which I found a box with contained a set of Dinner Dishes for 8 persons, she claimed that she did not know to whom they belonged or how they got there, the dishes were then taken along with me. I then proceeded to the Convent and there Sister Superior George identified all the articles which I then had in my possession, as being the articles which were stolen from the school house.

10. We then proceeded back to Montreal and JOHN CUROTTE was again questioned, he then admitted having stolen all the P.T.C.
stolen all the
from the School and that he was assisted by Gilbert LEBORGNE
in committing the theft. Gilbert LEBORGNE was then questioned
and he admitted having been with CUROTTE on the theft.
CUROTTE was then questioned about the articles which had not
been recovered, he stated that he had sold the Electric Iron
to Napoleon CUROTTE, the Electric Toaster to Mrs. Annie MONTOUR,
the cheaper silverware to Joe LEBORGNE and that he had given
and sold to different other persons other small articles, but
he did not remember to whom he had sold them.

11. Returning to Caughnawaga accompanied by Cst.
J. Cowan, I recovered the cheaper silverware from Mrs. Joe
LEBORGNE, but these articles had been transferred to her
mother's home Mrs. Angus LAHACHE on the St. Isidore Road. The
Iron was recovered from Napoleon CUROTTE, but at Mrs. Annie
MONTOUR'S she and her daughter denied having received the
Toaster, the daughter admitted having bought the Dinner set
from CUROTTE, at the time he claimed that he had won same at
a Fair. The Iron and cheaper silverware was identified by
the Nuns as their property.

12. John CUROTTE appeared on the A.M. of the 21st
inst. for Illegal possession of Firearms, he pleaded Guilty,
this accused and Gilbert LEBORGNE appeared before Judge C.B.
Guerin at Montreal on the afternoon of the 21st inst., on two
charges of B.& E. and Theft, namely the Golf Club and the
School house, charges being laid by the Que. Prov. Police, they
both pleaded Guilty and the case was remanded to June 25th
for sentence, in the meantime the two accuseds being sent
to jail.

13. In view of the fact that most of the prin-
cipal articles have been recovered with the exception of the
Electric Toaster, leaving besides that the Food chopper, 5
Gal. Iron Pails, 6 prs Scissors, 2 Bread Knives, 1 set of
Meat Knives, 2 doz paring knives and a few of other small
kitchen utensils, I would suggest that this file be closed,
because I am quite sure now that none of these articles will
be recovered, as the persons who have them will dispose of
the articles, knowing that we have already found some of the
goods.

14. Attached hereto please find F. 246 covering
the articles which have been recovered, may I be advised please
if these articles can be returned to the rightful owners, now
that the culprits have been arrested and pleaded guilty, your
instructions are awaited in this connection. No F. 2648s
being forwarded as the charges have been laid by the Que. Prov.
Police. Further report will be submitted in connection with
the sentence which is to be pronounced on June 25th 1943.

Teachers' Residence,
Caughnawaga, August 8, 1943.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Now that St. Regis Mission has become a new mission post for the Sisters of Saint Ann, I am able to submit the staff changes in Caughnawaga for the scholastic year 1943-1944.

Sister M. Mediatrix is replaced by Sr. M. Jeanne-du-Crucifix; Sister M. Lucie is replaced by Sister M. Rose-Dorothy; Sister M. Edward is replaced by Sr. M. Yvonne-Theresa; Sister Dorothy Hertle is named for St. Regis, therefore she will be replaced by Sr. Marie, a former Caughnawaga teacher.

The Mounted Police have returned most of the stolen articles for which we are grateful. We still hope for the remainder.

Answering your letter re file 5-1-4, with reference to Canadian Problem & Practice Arithmetic, we would require 50 books for Grades 3 & 4; 25 books for Grades 5 & 6 and 75 books for Grades 7 & 8 or

50 Book I
25 # II
75 # III

We would appreciate receiving 50 copies each of the Canadian Individual Arithmetics A, B, and C. We find these work books of great advantage to the children.

Regarding the 50 Ink Blanks for classroom preparations, these were black-covered ink books which the teachers use for their class preparation. In fact, any ink blank (heavier than the Maple Leaf) will do for this purpose.
According to all appearances, the fall registration is going to be quite heavy. We are planning how to accommodate all these children. However, we will wait until they are in before really worrying.

The paint job on the front verandah has transformed the residence. We are so grateful for this. The ice-box has been repaired several times since your last visit without much result.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Herewith enclosed, please find War Saving Stamps Applications, duly filled out, I hope. I am sorry that you had to return the others.

School reopened on the first of September with a registration of some 300 pupils for the two village schools, not counting the sixty odd pupils of 12 years or more who are still at work in the canneries. Will we leave these children at work until October 1st or shall we go after them now? The Compulsory School Attendance Law for Montreal obliges them (those of 14 or under) to return to school immediately. I will not do anything about this until I hear from you.

There are already 58 six and seven year old babies in the First Grade and some fifteen others asking for admission. We've moved four classes in an effort to give everybody breathing space and we have asked Mr. Brisebois for additional desks and chairs. Would it be possible to hire an extra Indian teacher to help with the work in this first class? Besides that, Miss Saylor who has been doing splendid teaching for the past four years, is tempted to leave us in order to earn more money elsewhere. Mr. Phelan, would it not be possible to give her an increase of $100.00 per year? She is now getting $65.00 per month. She is practically the sole support of her mother and of her brother.

Sr. M. Zita has written in from St. Regis asking for a typewriter. All the working machines were sent to Ottawa, since we kept only two for ourselves here, one in school and one at the residence. However, there is still a couple of old machines in storage here. Is it your intention that we have one of these repaired and forwarded to St. Regis?

The Domestic Science Room is opening its doors tomorrow with the first canning lesson of the season. Are the girls happy? We have twelve of them who will follow the course, though we do hope to convince a few others to take advantage of it......some of the girls we lost last year.

I wish to thank you for what you did for Eugene Skye. The boy certainly will be a credit to the Department. I did not ask for it personally because so many parents had been to the convent, asking for grants and I felt that all of them, excepting Eugene Skye, could well afford to pay for their children's education. I just answered that the Department had cancelled all grants as far as possible. That is your intention, is it not?

If you are down this way in the near future, remember that Caughnawaga doors are always open to receive you.

Dear Sirs,

RE FRENCH SCHOOL IN CAUGHNAWAGA.

Representatives from the Council of Caughnawaga have just been in to see me with regard to the formation of a school in the Caughnawaga Reserve for French Canadian children on the Reserve and point out to me that this an Indian Reserve.

They also point out that the present situation is just a further encroachment on their rights.

Through various means and devious ways French Canadians have come on the reserve and every time there was an objection there has been a postponement of the situation for some reason or other. Summer visitors have been tolerated for six months and then after being on the Reserve for six months, have dragged along until the following summer and then started another six months until they have become more or less permanent.

All of these various "visitors", I am told, have finally formed a small French community sufficiently large to require a French Canadian School. I am also informed that, of course, the Indian Agent, being a French-Canadian, has many visitors which all swells the French-Canadian population. I have been asked to point out to you that the Council understands that some of the equipment used for the proposed school belongs to the Indian Department and should be used for the benefit of the Indian pupils.

It has been particularly stressed to me that there is no race feeling against French, English or any other race but the Indians feel that Caughnawaga is an Indian Reserve and should be retained intact as such.

Please advise,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of September 9, in which you refer to certain representations that have been made to you by the members of the Council of the Caughnawaga Reserve, with respect to the organization of a French Canadian school on the reserve lands.

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant enclosing copy of a communication received by the Branch from Royal E.C.Werry, K.C., Montreal, Que., which is dealing with the establishment of a School on this Reserve for white children.

In reply I wish to inform that what an Indian woman, Mrs. Albert Rice a former teacher of Lachine has started to give private courses in her own home to white children living in this Village. She has at present 12 pupils. There is positively no equipment belonging to the Department of Indian Affairs used for the benefit of these children. Mrs. Rice started to teach these children at the request of their parents who although living here could not send their children to the local Schools and were unable to send them Ville-Leselle nor Lachine as the Schools of the two Towns are full to capacity. May I say that another Indian woman Mrs. Margaret Regis was giving private lessons to white pupils last year but discontinued this year. Mrs. Rice merely replaced her. I am enclosing a list of the pupils of Mrs. Rice.

As Mrs. Rice is a member of this Band selling her services to white people, as a merchant would sell his goods or a workman his time or skill, and that she does not run a bona fide school but gives private courses it is not believed that she can prevented to do so, as she uses her residence and not a building which should be classified as a school house.

As to Mr. Werry's statement that I have many visitors who are swelling the French Canadian population, I may say that when I have outside visitors coming for an evening or a day at my home they do swell the population for the time that they spend at my home but as they only come for short visits it is not the Councillors' business nor his own. This statement could be understood coming directly from the Councillors but not from a so-called serious lawyer.

Dear Sir:

May I refer to your letter to this Department dated September 9 and my reply thereto dated September 13, 1943?

I am today in receipt of a letter from Indian Agent Brisebois, in which he states that no attempt has been made to organize a school district or to establish a public school on the Caughnawaga reserve at any time. The Indian Agent points out, however, that Mrs. Albert Rice, a member of the Caughnawaga Band, is at present providing tuition for 12 pupils. Of these pupils, five are French speaking and seven English speaking. However, the course of instruction provided is English. It would appear also, from the information supplied us, that Mrs. Margaret Regis gave somewhat similar instruction to a group of Indians last year. Mr. Brisebois, in commenting upon the instruction that has been provided until now, states: "Mrs. Rice is a member of this Band, selling her services to white people as a merchant would sell his goods or a workman his time or skill. She does not operate a school but provides private courses and uses her own residence for this purpose."

Mr. Brisebois concludes his letter with the statement that an attempt has been made by the parents of these children to send them to Ville Lasalle and Lachine but that the schools at these points are now full to capacity.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

We have been advised by our lay teacher, Miss Inez Saylor, that she proposes to be married on December 27th of this year.

As Miss Saylor is to marry a service man, she asks if she may be allowed to continue teaching in the Caughnawaga schools for the duration, if possible. As we have already told you, Miss Saylor is a very competent teacher especially with the younger children and we would be very sorry to lose her. However, we have made her understand that it is not the Department's custom to hire married women but we are submitting the matter to you for decision.

Mr. Bush is a little worried for he has received no salary at all since he began work for us on October 14th. Will you kindly see to this matter also?

Our General Prefect of English Studies is presently examining the Caughnawaga classes. We will ask her to make a report to the Department at the close of her visit.
The furnace at the Kateri School has been out of order for the past three days. We have been forced to have the girls stay home, providing them with plenty of written work.

Most of our truants are now back in school. We are certainly getting 100% cooperation from the M.P.'s, who are real gentlemen and who will eventually win the Indians over. Many Indians are ashamed of last week's happenings and have expressed sympathy for the two on the reserve. They have been very kind in their dealings with the children, though they have made them understand that they will be firm. God permitted the fight for the greater good of the majority of people living on the Caughnawaga Reserve, though the going is tough for the present.

With kind personal regards, we beg to remain

Very respectfully yours,

SISTERS OF SAINT ANN

Dear Sister Mary George:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, with reference to payment of bonus to Mrs. Bush, teacher of the Caughnawaga Bush School.

Married women whose husbands are also employed in the Government service were not entitled to receive bonus previous to November 1, 1943. Mrs. Bush was paid bonus for October, but subsequently a cheque was issued for Mr. Bush from October 15, 1943, and consequently, according to the ruling in effect at that time, Mrs. Bush had been overpaid bonus for the period October 15 to October 31, 1943, amounting to $7.46.

From November 1, 1943, a new regulation went into effect permitting the payment of bonus to both a husband and a wife, although both of them are in Government employ. Consequently in future Mrs. Bush will continue to draw bonus at the rate of $7.46 a month, but, in view of the overpayment of $7.46 for the period October 15 to October 31, this amount was deducted from her December bonus leaving the balance due her $6.14. Study Beatification Of Nine Canadians

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 6. — (AP) — Catherine Tekakwitha, Iroquois Indian who died in 1680 at the age of 22, soon may be beatified. This is the last stage before being declared a saint.

Beatification of nine Canadians and six Americans is being considered.

The Canadians under consideration are:

Francis de Montmorency Laval, first Bishop of Quebec, who died in 1708; Ludwig Moreau, Bishop of St. Hyacinthe, who died June 23, 1901; first Bishop of St. Albert, who died in 1902; Margaret Bourgeoys, founder of the Sisters of Our Lady, who died in Montreal in 1673; Mary of the Incarnation, who founded the order of the Ursuline Sisters of Quebec, and died in 1672; Mary Marguerite Durost de Lajemmerais, founder of the Grey Nuns of Montreal, who died in 1771; Rose Duroche, founder of the Holy Name Sisters of Montreal, who died in 1845; the Redemptionist missionary Alfred Pampalon, who was born in Belgium and died in Quebec in 1691, and the Augustinian Sister, Mary Catherine of St. Augustine, who died in Quebec in 1688.

Your letter of the 28th instant dealing with the children of three white families allegedly attending School on this Reserve has been received. This matter was taken up immediately with the Sister Superior and I may say that there are no children by the names of La Guignere or Joubert nor are there to my knowledge any families by that name at Caughnawaga.

Relative to the names of four children named in your letter, they are the children of Mr. Telesphore Payreau a white farmer who has been living at Caughnawaga for over 15 years. He is a tenant on an Indian farm under Departmental lease No.464.

In connection with their attendance at the local Schools I may say that when the decision to exclude white children from the Schools was arrived at in 1939 it was understood that the children of white farmers occupying farms under official leases would be permitted to attend as they were not trespassers. It was further understood that no white children whose family were residing in the Village could obtain permission as the Department and the Indians did not want outsiders to remain within the limits of the Village for the entire year but only for the Summer months. The cases of the farmers however were considered to be different as if a farmer is permitted to live here it is only logical that his children be received at the Schools. If you examine the Attendance reports of the years past you will note that the Payreau's children have attended the local School regularly for a good number of years. They have not been discharged from School but will be when you notify me of the change of attitude of the Branch as regards to farmers.

It is quite apparent that your informer or informers have exaggerated the number of white pupils at the Schools of Caughnawaga.

(Frs. Brisebois)

Dear Mr. Phelan:

We acknowledge receipt of your letter dated January 14th asking for information on the teaching staff of Caughnawaga. You will find these sheets herein enclosed and fully filled. We trust that they are satisfactory.

Of course, you must realize that the main topic of conversation here in Caughnawaga is the project of the new school. Yesterday, we had a long conversation with Father Lalonde and we came to the conclusion that it would be advantageous to all concerned if you, Mr. Phelan, or Mr. Donet—preferably both of you came to Caughnawaga within the next week or two as there is an important proposition we would like to discuss with you.

Furthermore, we believe that Reverend Brother General who has just returned from British Columbia would appreciate an interview with you also. He is scheduled to return to the Pacific Coast and Alaska within the next few weeks.

Would it be presumptuous of us to ask if we might have the plans of the new school for a few days in order to study them more thoroughly? This favor would be greatly appreciated.

Hoping to meet you very soon, we remain

Respectfully yours,

Dear Sister George:

Mr. Doucet has referred to me your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to the S. S. C. A. meeting in Montreal. I note that to attend this would involve closing approximately one week sooner than the regular closing date. Such action always brings certain repercussions. If we allow it at your school, we will have to do the same with the other schools on the reserve, and then possibly we will have a similar request from the Sisters at St. Regis. If that is granted, it will mean closing all the other schools in the St. Regis Agency. This may not seem very reasonable to you, but it is what actually happens.

Is it the intention that all the Sisters at Caughnawaga would attend the sessions of the Congress? Is it absolutely essential that they should attend all sessions? Would it not be possible for some to attend one day and some another? In that manner the school could be kept in operation until the recognized closing date. I would appreciate it if you would give this matter further consideration.

Dear Sir:

We the Councillors of Taughnawaga at a special meeting have unanimously approved to inform you that plans are being made by a small group of people to petition the Department to bring in an order of Brothers to teach our children.

Be so informed, that we are opposed and will oppose any attempt to bring any organized order of Brothers on our Reservation for any purpose, because we have no place and use for them.

We passed a Resolution last July 1946 opposing any attempt to bring Brothers as teachers, but we are desirous of having lay teachers same as Protestant School Board of Island of Montreal; also young men and women of our own kind who are qualified to fill these positions.
We would sincerely appreciate if your Department will disregard any Petitions of the above nature, without the consent of the Band in question.

I remain

Dear Sir,

Under separate cover we are forwarding you today application forms filled out by our teachers. We have done our best to follow the instructions given in the bulletin, No. 4. We submit them to you for your approval; should you find we have made mistakes in classifying ourselves, especially mistakes in our favor, we shall be pleased with the correction....

No doubt you are aware that many of the books and articles listed on our requisition have not yet been sent in, for instance pencils, covering paper, etc., etc. May we hope to have these within a short time? Authorization also to buy the cleaning articles for the schools and for our residence has not yet been sent either.

A new program of studies for the English Catholic schools of the Province of Que. is adopted this school year. There will be a Teachers' Convention in Montreal on the 18th and 19th of this month. The agent here, Mr. Brisebois allows us to close our schools for these two days so that the teachers may attend this convention. Does this meet with your approval, Sir?

With the aim of helping our pupils who wish to continue their education after they have completed eighth or ninth grades in our school, we wish to add Latin and French to our program of studies. May we have the authorization of ordering forty-two of each of these text books from the Montreal Book Room? The Department has already ordered books for our schools from this place.
We wish to recommend Rejeanne Giasson for a renewal of her grant at St. Angela's Boarding School; it is One Hundred Dollar grant. This pupil came out first in her class last year. Marilyn Mylow, a pupil who graduated from our ninth grade last June wishes to obtain a One Hundred Dollar grant to begin her classical course at St. Angela's Boarding School, Montreal. Josie Jacobs, a pupil for whom we have recently asked for a One Hundred Dollar grant, asks to have One Hundred and Fifty Dollars instead. Her father is a sickly man and the family is poor. The girl wishes to take a Comptometer course at the same time as her commercial course.

We thank you, Sir, for the kind interest shown to all our problems. We wish to assure you of a cordial welcome to our classes upon your next visit to Caughnawaga.

Yours sincerely,

Sr. Mary Albertus

Dear Sir,

You may not be aware that we are anxiously awaiting a reply to the list of requests we sent you in our letter of Oct. 14th. Since then, though, we did receive a good supply of pencils, rulers, books for our First Grade, etc. However, the teachers are still very much in need of some of the books requested, also of cleaning articles, drinking pails and cups, balls, etc., etc. May we count on your kindness to send us a favorable reply this week?

We are enclosing today the application blank of one of our teachers. We are sorry to say we overlooked her when we sent in our own blanks for new salaries, otherwise we would have gladly included her paper with ours.

Our Physical Culture teacher who has begun to give her lessons in the Parish Hall finds a great improvement already in the pupils' exercises.

Mr. Viau came to visit our Manual Training Room this afternoon and told us about Mr. Doucet's offer to him. We are favorably impressed with this first interview.

With renewed expression of our hope of receiving a favorable answer this week, Sir, we remain,

Pour l'éducation des Indiens

Ottawa ne oublie pas les Indiens du Canada. On constate en effet, à l'étude des principales prévisions budgétaires déposées à la Chambre des Communes, que le gouvernement demande au Parlement d'augmenter de façon considérable le crédit en faveur de l'éducation des Indiens.

L'hon. M. Glen a précisé que le ministère des Mines et des Ressources, qu'il dirige, se propose d'aménager quatre-vingts nouveaux externats et quatre nouveaux pensionnats dans les endroits isolés. On corrigera ainsi une situation qui ne saurait durer plus longtemps, car un grand nombre de jeunes Indiens d'âge scolaire ne bénéficient pas encore des avantages de l'enseignement.

Si l'on veut que l'Indien contribue pleinement à la collectivité canadienne, il faut, ainsi que l'a souligné M. Glen, que l'éducation commence chez l'enfant.

Notons qu'au programme des institutions scolaires projetées pour les Indiens, nos voisins de Caughnawaga ne sont pas oubliés. On a l'intention de construire en cet endroit un externat de douze classes, pouvant recevoir 350 enfants. C'est l'établissement le plus
L'élection se fera-t-elle sur l'hôtel-Dieu de Québec ou sur l'administration de M. Duplessis ?

Comme M. Duplessis a l'air tout à fait décidé de trainer les religieuses hospitalières de l'hôtel-Dieu de Québec sur le terrain du plus bas électoralisme et d'associer étroitement leur nom aux vulgaires méthodes démagogiques dont il vient de donner un autre échantillon au Salon de la Race, il sera du devoir des citoyens de faire entendre leur voix contre cette politique.

Il convient de féliciter le gouvernement fédéral du souci qu'il témoigne d'assurer les bienfaits de l'instruction à tous les membres de la communauté canadienne. L'enseignement est un domaine provincial, c'est entendu; mais les Indiens, par leur statut spécial, échappant à la juridiction des provinces, c'est le devoir de l'autorité fédérale de leur procurer les moyens de s'instruire comme tous les Canadiens. Et Ottawa prouve qu'il n'en tend pas se dérober à ce devoir.

DIRECTOR, LANDS and DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH.

Caughnawaga Indian Day School

Our Education Division officials have had a visit from the Reverend Father Lalonde, S.J., the Missionary at the Caughnawaga Reserve.

He advises that arrangements are being made for the Jesuits to assume the educational supervision of the new school at Caughnawaga.

This has been planned for some time, as it was felt that while the Sisters of Saint Ann were doing excellent work with the girls, similar progress was not being made with the older boys.

It is our understanding that the younger boys and girls will continue to be educated by the Sisters but that the older boys will be taught by Jesuit Priests and Brothers. Therefore, it is recommended that, if possible, one minor change be made in the first floor plan of the Caughnawaga school. Could the small partition be placed in the corner of the teacher's room (109) and a toilet and wash-stand placed in this room for the use of male teachers. Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY.

Inspection of Caughnawaga R.C. Indian Day School.

I had an opportunity while in Montreal to visit Caughnawaga. I was somewhat disappointed with the construction of the new school. Its progress is not what it should be. This is due probably to the difficulty of obtaining material and skilled labour. However, I believe that our architects should endeavour to visit this building and see what can be done to expedite the construction of it. At the rate that they are going at present, they will have a great deal of difficulty working during the winter as none of the walls of the main building are even partially enclosed.

I had a fairly lengthy talk with the new Principal of the school. I visited Miss Terrance's room and I am satisfied that under supervision she is doing her work here as efficiently as possible. The Principal is aware of the reason of her transfer and is following her fairly closely.

I also visited several other classrooms and was pleased with the spirit and atmosphere in Miss Bush's room. I was not impressed with the arithmetic achieved in the senior boys' room. I think that this is probably one of the weak spots in the Caughnawaga schools.
I have noticed that most of the teachers are new. I was somewhat disappointed because the various talks given to these teachers on the activity program has been to a great extent wasted time. The Principal herself is not familiar with our recommendation on this line and the seven new Sisters probably never heard about it. I feel that the amount of money that we are putting in education at Caughnawaga entitles us to, I would say, better treatment as far as teachers are concerned.

I visited the Manual Training class and am satisfied with the progress being made. Mr. Viau has quite an influence on his pupils. He has good discipline and seems to be well liked by his pupils. Of course, the accommodation is far from being satisfactory. A number of minor mistakes have been made which could have serious repercussions but I believe that I have been able to rectify these in time. This again is due to our inability to visit these schools more frequently.

Respectfully submitted,

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor of Vocational Training.

Dear Sir:

The Easter holidays mark the last stages of the school year. I trust that they offered you the well-deserved relaxation after a heavy winter session and the opportunity of freshening up for the spring and summer rush—I don't suppose that summer lull exists for you. Since the date of your promised visit is so uncertain, I am taking the liberty of writing you about the various points and situations with which Time has the gift of strewing our path.

First, Sister Mary Anne Rosaleen, teacher of Grades IX and VIII Boys, was transferred to our Infirmary in Lachine on April 11 where she will remain till the summer. As no other substitute could be had, Sister Evelina Marie, our Physical Culture instructor, was appointed to replace her. Despite the fact that none of us favor substitution during the school year, I am confident that you will understand that this change is necessitated by inevitable circumstances beyond our control.

This in turn gives rise to another situation. You are fully aware that it is not feasible to exact Sister Evelina Marie to fulfill both duties; but as there are only a few weeks left, the respective class teachers would be willing to continue the drills with their individual classes if you allowed extra compensation for this extra work. From the very beginning, Sister promised the pupils a public demonstration as an incentive to their best effort. Not to disappoint them, the Sisters would be willing to lend a helping hand.
Yet I do not think it would be fair to tax the teachers with this extra task without some suitable remuneration. Should you decide otherwise, we shall simply abide by your decision and drop the physical training. I am sorry for the disturbance this change will cause in the Department of Finance; but as I stated above, this condition could not be avoided nor controlled.

The third point concerns the moving to the new school which is progressing quite well. If I remember well, you mentioned last November that this would take place before the pupils left for their holidays as it would be too onerous to do it alone. Now, would you want us to transfer only the school supplies? Do you intend furnishing the new school with entirely new equipment or shall we prepare the old for transportation too?

These and many other minor question marks would be quickly discussed and settled "viva voce"--shall we have the pleasure of receiving you soon?

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

P.S. We have written to the Ontario Department of Education in Toronto for details concerning the summer courses they offer for teachers. If at all manageable, some of us will no doubt attend.

RESOLUTION 3115.

Proposed by Chief Councillor Harry Beauvais, seconded by Frank A. Goodleaf, whereas ninety-six per cent of the Indian population of Canada belongs to the Christian Faith, in one denomination or another; whereas the Christian Faith is the cornerstone of the civilization both of the Governments with which our ancestors have signed treaties, and of the people of Canada in whose midst we are now living; whereas it is the will of the majority of our people to have their children brought up in this Christian Faith; whereas experience has proved that the best means of procuring such an education reside in the denominational school as opposed to the so-called neutral public school; whereas we have enjoyed from the very beginning of our dealings with the Federal Government in matters of education, the right to send our children to denominational schools of our Faith where they are taught Christian religion and trained in Christian morals as well as schooled in secular learning; whereas the actual Indian Act acknowledges both this fact and this right by providing for denominational schools only; we do hereby request of the Parliament of Canada that, in revising the Act, nothing be changed in Section 10 and 100 concerning denominational schools and that no system of neutral schools be introduced on our Reserves in any way, shape or form. We declare that, by virtue of 158 (Section) of the present Indian Act, we are hereby voicing the opinion of the majority of our band in the above matters.

Voted. 7 for. and 1 against.
Carried.

Col. Bernard F. Neary

OTTAWA

Dear Sir:

The first week of August is ending and still no news of moving into the beautiful new school. The finishing touches are lingering and the opening date of the school term is just one month ahead.

We are not exactly worrying about it, but we must admit that we are really anxious about the moving, the necessary new equipment, and the numerous details of installation. The weekly promise of Mr. Bock's "taking possession" keeps us in hopes...and no doubt that the "real" day is just around the corner.

In the meantime, our yearly appointments took place—only two changes on our teaching staff: Sr. Mary Cabrini and Sr. Mary Bernard of Siena. I am enclosing their Employee Questionnaire forms duly filled in. Sr. Mary Cabrini has already been with us; and though her status must be in your files, I thought it would save time for your different Departments involved to have her fill in another form. The teaching staff for the school year 1949-50 is as follows:

Sr. Marie Sr. M. Bernard of Siena
Sr. M. Jeanne-du-Crucifix Sr. M. George Ernest
Sr. Evelina Marie Sr. M. Alma (Dom. Science)
Sr. Mary Roseline Miss Charlotte Bush
Sr. Mary Louis Richard Mrs. Wilfrid Rice (Dom. Science)
Sr. Mary Cabrini Sr. M. Mediatrix, Principal

You are no doubt waiting for this information before sending us the Qualifications blanks necessary for proper classification and salary notification.

Last June when we spoke of the Official Opening of the school, you promised to send us a definite program. Would it be too early to ask for this program now...we
would like to have the music and address ready for rehearsal when school opens. You will agree that from now till then Time is making itself rather short. So any preparation that we can see to during the holidays will only save a last-minute rush.

Would you approve our taking a few former pupils to help us execute our Official Opening program? Besides appreciating the great honor, they would be really lending us "main forte."

We sincerely trust that your visit to Gaughnawaga will not delay so that we may discuss the several important minor details concerning the coming school year.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]
Principal

Enc. 2

P.S. Please accept our hearty congratulations for the fine handling of the school requisition. The Manager of the Stationery Department certainly deserves an Honorable mention for his outstanding despatch efficiency!

You will be good enough to take the necessary steps to secure the services of a competent teacher to take charge of this school after the summer holidays, all applications accompanied by recommendations and testimonials to be submitted to the Department. MEMORANDUM

Re teacher for Caughnawaga Indian Boys school

An application has been received through Mr Agent Brosseau from Mr Omer Plante for the position of teacher of the Caughnawaga Boys school in place of Mr Jacobs who has been dismissed. Mr Plante holds a diploma issued by the Mohawk Institute, which is recognized by the Department as entitling the holder to teach an Indian school.

Mr Brown M.P. personally recommended the above applicant, and the only question as to his suitability to manage such a large school, is his youth and inexperience. If however, it is decided to engage him, his appointment might be made temporarily.

Four hundred and fifty dollars ($450) is provided for the salary of the teacher of this school. The undersigned would suggest that the new teacher be appointed at the rate of $300 per annum, with an increase of $1:50 per quarter for every unit of average attendance over 25, until the full salary provided is reached. There are about 200 pupils who should attend this school, but from carelessness on the part of the late teacher and apathy of the parents the average attendance has gradually fallen to 16 for the past year.

This is one of the schools where the Regulations for compulsory attendance should be enforced, and it would be well to do so at once that the new teacher may have a fair start.

The number of boys that should attend this school is given as about two hundred. The enrollment is at present forty-four with an average attendance of about twenty-one. This, I consider is very unsatisfactory.

The Secretary:

I beg to call your attention to Mr Agent Brosseau's report on the Caughnawaga Boys school for the month of November last in which he states that the number of pupils in attendance is larger than one teacher can properly look after.

There are 106 pupils enrolled at this school out of a total school population of 200 boys of the reserve. The average attendance is about 45 who are in the first four standards and most of the teacher's time is devoted to the younger pupils who form the greatest number. It seems to me that an assistant is required at this school, forty pupils being about the limit allowed to one teacher in the public schools where they are all of one grade. Good results cannot be obtained in a school of this class where the pupils are in four different standards.

The attendance under Mr Delisle, the present teacher, has more than doubled, and I think that still better results could be obtained if he had more time to devote to the older pupils. The quarterly returns show that the ages of the pupils run from six to sixteen.

The Girls school on this reserve, which has about the same average attendance though a smaller enrollment, has two teachers and is doing good work.

There
There are three schools on this reserve, two Roman Catholic (Boys and Girls) with a school population of about 200 each and an attendance as above stated, and one Methodist school with an enrollment of 6 and an average attendance of 3 pupils. The appropriation for these schools is $450.00 for the Boys (the amount paid being $400.00); $500 for the Girls ($300.00 for the senior teacher and $200.00 for the junior); $250.00 for the Methodist, ($125.00 being paid by the Department through the Methodist Missionary Society) which leaves $175.00 for the appropriation voted for salaries unspent, which might be used in paying the salary of a second teacher for the Boys School and I think that if a small amount were added by the Department there would be no difficulty in getting a teacher to take charge of the junior class.

The present building used by the Boys has ample accommodation for two classes, there being two rooms of 25 x 22 ft each.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Mr. Peter Williams, assistant teacher of the Caughnawaga Boys' school has applied for an increase in salary. He is at present in receipt of $300 per annum and has been in the employ of the Department since January, 1903 at his present salary. He claims that this salary, owing to the increased cost of living, is not sufficient for the maintenance of himself and family. This application is renewing a former one made two years ago, when he was told that the Department did not see its way to pay him more than he was then receiving.

He is an educated Indian and has given satisfaction as far as his work goes and he has the largest class in the school and is not provided with anything further than his salary. The head teacher receives $450 and house and heating. Caughnawaga is an expensive place to live in, and nearly all the young Indians of Williams' age are earning double his wages, and Williams could easily do better if he were to leave the reserve. It would be a difficult matter to replace him, as no white man would take the position for the salary offered. He has had nearly four years' experience, has the confidence of the parents and Mr. School Inspector Zippens speaks favourably of him in his reports.

I know there is no provision for a higher salary at present, but I think the time has arrived when the Department will have to face the question of increasing the salaries of some of the teachers if they wish to retain their services. Frequent changes are not conducive to the welfare of a school, and I would suggest that, if funds can be spared, Mr. Williams be granted an increase of about $100.

Referring to the letter from Mr. Delisle, Principal of the Caughnawaga Boys' School, in which he asks for an increase of salary, a grant in lieu of rent and assistance in the education of one of his children, I beg to say, with regard to salary, that Mr. Delisle is in receipt of the sum of $500.00 a year, which is the highest salary paid to our teachers in the province of Quebec. He has a large school and the average attendance for the last quarter was 106, as shown by the return. He is reported to be doing good work in the school and has been in charge for the last twelve years. While Mr. Delisle has no professional qualifications, he has had a great deal of experience and is conversant with Iroquois, French and English and is popular with the tribe.

Mr. Delisle is correct in his statement that ever since the school has been conducted a residence has been provided for the teacher, as the old building in which the
the school was held afforded ample room for teacher's quarters. The building of the new school necessitated his abandoning these quarters, which are used for other purposes, and Mr. Delisle has been obliged to find living accommodation elsewhere and I think he is quite justified in claiming compensation. I think that $100.00 a year would be a fair amount to allow him for the loss that he has sustained in having to provide a house for himself.

Mr. Delisle would be entitled to the $60.00 grant we are allowing other Indians to continue the education of deserving pupils.

I think that it would be better to make Mr. Delisle a $100.00 rent allowance than to increase his salary and he would have no complaint if this were done.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Pedley,

With reference to the resolution of the Caughnawaga Indian Council hereunder, protecting against the school children attending Church for religious instruction during the School hours. I beg to say that while on the reserve Dr. Patton, Chief Councilor and some other members of the Band brought this matter to my notice. When visiting the schools, I asked the teachers and truant officer for an explanation for the small attendance, on the days I called at the schools I was informed that it was owing to the children being prepared for their first communion and confirmation by the Missionaries. When I called on Father Granger I found him and his assistant engaged in instructing 65 school children in the Church, in their religious duties, and he explained to me that it was necessary to take them out of the schools for the purpose, as the religious teaching had to be given in Iroquois as they were not sufficiently familiar with English to thoroughly understand religious teaching in that language. Father Granger told me that while the teachers of the Boys' and Bush Schools were Indians he did not
not consider them competent to give the necessary instruction.

I am creditly informed that in all the Roman Catholic Schools throughout the Province of Quebec and even in the separate schools of Ontario it is the practice for the priests and missionaries to take charge of the religious teaching necessary to fit children for their first communion and confirmation, during school hours and for the greater portion of the school day even in cities and towns, while in rural districts the whole time is devoted to this work.

From what I have heard and know, of some of the Caughnawaga Indians and of Dr. Patton in particular, I am led to believe that this complaint is made more in pique, than for the interest of the school children. It is the desire of the Missionaries at Caughnawaga to make the Indians under their care good Catholics and I do not consider that it would be politic to hamper them in their efforts to do so.

Dear Mr. Scott,

In view of the change recently effected in the system of management of the village school at Caughnawaga whereby I have been enforced to retire after an uninterrupted service of fourteen years, and during a period of unusual depression combined with my own peculiar circumstances, all prospects to obtain an opening are consequently precluded.

The Department as my employer knows
my work perfectly well; and as regards general educational interest, I am happy to possess the favourable commentations of such gentlemen as Mr. Abbott of Washington St., Mr. Dobbs of Byrne, Switz, and I can say, of all the school inspectors whose reports I can show, and for my people I feel flattered to state that they are sorry to lose me! I am on the street today, greatly concerned for my town and family of three children. I must do something, what have I, that would influence my chance, save my own confidence in appealing to your love of justice to which I commit myself.
Mr Scott I am conscious of the one fact that I should not have remained a teacher so long, and I selfishly believe that some few gentlemen, with whom I had the pleasure and honour to have a passing acquaintance, have a little thought for me; my education and ability will not avail my purpose without influential aid. I know I have no legal claim but on the strength of the moral side of my case I make this earnest request for your kindly interest in my behalf to secure for me a continued appointment; place and nature immaterial. Thanking you for your worthy consideration.

Ottawa, March 3rd, 1917.

I beg to report that in pursuance with your instructions I called upon Mr. and Mrs. Joe Canadien in reference to their complaint against the sisters of the Caughnawaga Boys' School for alleged discrimination against their boys and for ill-treatment as well.

They stated that their boys, Charlie and Angus, were objects of personal spite by the sisters; the oldest boy was picked on as a scapegoat for some lies circulated casting reflection on the conduct of the sisters, while the youngest one was given severe corporal punishment which resulted in injury to his ear necessitating his being attended to by the doctor; the boys were expelled from the school and would not be allowed to return unless they apologized to the sisters and the missionary.

I called upon the truant officer, Martin Twoaxe, for his version of the matter and he corroborated almost all the statements made by the Canadiens*. He ventured to state that he thought the sisters were unduly severe with these two boys, and should show a little more patience in their treatment with the Indian children. I also called upon Dr. Jacobs, who attended the boy for his ear, and he informed me that the ear trouble was a long standing and chronic one, nothing whatever to do with the punishment given the boy by the teacher at school.

I called on the Sister Superior and the Sister who had the supervision of the boys' school and they both emphatically denied the charges made by Mr. and Mrs. Canadien, and pronounced same as fabrication of falsehoods.

*Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6076, file 305-1B, part 1)
They stated that the boys were exceptionally unruly and insubordinate for which they were punished mildly, telling the youngest one that "if he did not behave himself better than he has been he would have to seek another school".

The Sisters assured me that the boys were welcome to return to school at any time, but must obey the teachers.

I advised Mr. and Mrs. Canadien to send the youngest one back to school at once, and asked them to join him to behave himself in school and obey his teachers. They promised to comply with my request and I am in hopes that there will be no further cause of complaint from that source. With regard to the oldest one, Charlie, I did not urge them to send him back to school as he is practically fifteen years old and rather big for his age.

I should like to state that it is evident there exists an ill-feeling between the sisters and the Indians. The Indians generally are not backward in expressing their dislike of the sisters, while the latter, from my conversation had with them, they made use freely certain phraseology which showed their feelings towards these people which lacked the tone of sympathy. It would therefore be no matter of surprise if there were disagreements of this sort reported to the Department from time to time.

Your obedient servant,
