Caughnawaga, March 1, 1917.

Dear Sir:

I have to write you concerning Angus Canadian, son of Mr. Joseph Canadian of Caughnawaga.

This family has been doing us more harm with their tongues than all the villagers put together.

If the parents did not take care of the child, we would not have any trouble, but when a man says: "I do not want you to touch my boy, or I'll fix you" just as if we spend our time ill-treating them. He even named children in the classroom to spy the teacher.

It takes the patience of a saint to endure him, and when a teacher has 30 or more pupils to supervise she has no time to spend coaxing or petting Angus Canadian.

In school they have to toe the mark if they wish to learn. He has been stubborn, disobedient, impudent and lazy.

I was told he blames us if he has sore ears. We know he is deaf, but, if Almighty God gave him that infirmity it is not our fault, moreover he has the first seat near the teacher's desk, and if he wants to listen he has every opportunity.

In December he was behaving badly and disturbing the whole class, so Sister said: "Angus Canadian if you are not able to keep up to your promise I am afraid you will have to look for another school." There is a vast difference in that saying, and in telling a pupil: "Not to come back after Christmas." That is what he has been saying through the village.

We did not put him out, we never put any child out, but, Mr Benson, I warned the boy before the Truant Officer.
if he did not be polite and obedient that I would not have anything to do with him or his parents, but I WOULD REFER his case to the Department itself in the name of Mr Benson who has charge of the schools. It is a decided affair that we are not going to let ourselves be led by children.

I KNOW you understand our position and that you will continue helping us for the good of those Indians.

I shall inform you occasionally of his conduct and I HOPE YOU WILL pardon me if I took up so much of your time reading this long epistle.

I am, dear Sir,

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Mr Martin Benson,
Superintendent of Stationary,

OTTAWA, 22nd April, 1903

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Miss Street, who is in charge of the Caughnawaga Girls school, applies on behalf of herself and her assistant, Mrs Beauvais, for an increase of salary of $100.00 each. Miss Street's present salary is $300.00 and Mrs Beauvais receives $200.00 per annum.

This school is doing well under its present teachers and they think they are entitled to an increase on account of the cost of living. Miss Street called at the office during the Easter vacation and drew attention to the difference between the salaries paid the teachers of the Girls school and the Boys school at this place. The head teacher of the latter school receives $450.00 a year and his assistant $300.00, while the average attendance at each school is about the same, being about 40 pupils.

Mr Inspector Lippens reports favorably of the work done by Miss Street and her assistant and Mr Ross of this Department, who was lately in Caughnawaga, tells me that he was much pleased with what he saw at the Girls school.

The salaries are certainly low and I think that if $50.00 a year could be added to each, it would be an encouragement to them and only a fair recognition of their services.

There are a great many children of school age on the Caughnawaga reserve and under the present
management there has been a marked improvement in the attendance.

To the Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Sir,

I have been ordered by the Mayor of Caughnawaga to collect $5 a month from the French children attending Kateri Tekakwitha School and to report the same to you every three months through the agent. While quite prepared to do my duty and fulfill the orders of the Department, I wish to protest against being made a collector of money, which seems tome outside a Teacher's province. This matter is extremely delicate.

It appears tome to be a Teacher's duty to promote peace and concord among her pupils, instead of exciting race feeling by making distinctions.

Since I have been here it has been my endeavour to promote peace and allay
it feeling in every way in my power. The question of the Indians receiving money from the children is also a very delicate one for her, and I cannot see any way of getting myself in that awkward position.

I found it difficult to make a list of French children, as I do not know the genealogy of each family, nor is it my business, nor have I time and inclination to inquire. I sent the names of six children who, I was told, were French. I now find out that four of these are Indians in the eyes of the Department. Would it not be better if the Mayor, one of the Commissioners, or the Constable should collect this money from the parents? I cannot undertake to receive it.

Hoping this matter may be arranged to the satisfaction of everybody,

Believe me,

Yours faithfully,

M. E. Howlett.

Would Bar Religious Orders Except Jesuits From Caughnawaga.

School disputes are not confined to Ottawa, according to J. P. Delisle, of the Caughnawaga Indian reserve, who is here to enter a protest with the Department of Indian Affairs against a proposed change in the educational system of the reserve.

It is proposed to have the teaching on the reserve done in future by an order of nuns, to replace the present lay teachers. The idea was met with favor among the Indians, who have held several meetings to protest against the alteration. At the last, Mr. Delisle was selected to carry the objections of the Indians to the government.

At the conclusion of this meeting Mr. Delisle displayed a petition written in the Indian language, setting forth the objections of the members of the reserve to any change. The petition protests against the government granting permission to "any religious order" to reside within the limits of the reserve or to preside in any of the schools.

Sir,

Yesterday evening, the 28th inst., I had the pleasure of attending at the distribution of prizes in the Caughnawaga schools under the direction of the Sisters of Ste. Anne. On that occasion the good sisters had arranged a nice little dramatic and musical evening, which charmed me very much. I came back with the idea that our young Indians of Caughnawaga can compare with advantage beside any other nationality of the country. I noticed in these young children an air of intelligence that struck me. Their English pronunciation is good, and their manner in appearing before the public is without reproach. I am under the impression that the education of my young Indians is in good hands; and I should say that for Caughnawaga there is being prepared a new mentality that will be for the greatest good of the Iroquois of this reserve. The predecessors of the nuns were certainly good school-masters and school-mistresses; but permit me to make the remark, Mr. Superintendent, that for our Indians I attach more importance to education than to instruction. The formation of the character of a young Indian is the main point; and I do not hesitate to say that the nuns are more competent than any one else in this respect. The children appear to like their teachers and have great respect for them. In a word, I am quite satisfied with the manner in which these ladies are conducting their schools.

I have, &c.,

J.M. Brosseau,
Indian Agent.

October 30, 1915.

Dear Madam,

I have much pleasure in acknowledging the receipt of your programme of studies at the Caughnawaga schools, and I have looked over this with interest. At present I would not suggest any definite changes; I sent for it expressly for the purpose of seeing what time you are allowing for devotional exercises, catechism and religious instruction. Some of the Indians who profess opposition to the present management stated to me that too much time was so occupied, and that the educational interests of the children were correspondingly neglected.

I am putting you frankly in possession of this criticism so that you may be able to reply to me if you think it necessary.

Yours very truly,

Rev. Sister Mary Edward,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Principal,
Caughnawaga Indian Schools,
Caughnawaga, Que.
Montreal, Que.
Nov 14, 1875

Mr. Benson,
Ottawa.

Esteemed Sir,

I wish to ascertain whether or not my discharge came from Ottawa. I have been teaching in the Boys' School in Caughnawaga since the arrival of the Sister in January last until October 28th, when I received my discharge on 24 hours notice and told that my services were no longer required. The reason assigned was that I had no diploma and that the Ottawa people had complained.

If such be the case why not have complained before since I am led to believe Sister Mary Edward fully notified Ottawa of this before my going to teach there.
Why did you not give sufficient notice or something like that engage me for another term and discharge me at the end of two months without sufficient warning?

As far as I can find out after two weeks search that is the only cause of my dismissal. I wish to state that I have had no trouble with the Indian people. I always found them courteous even those opposed to the Sisters.

Someone has attacked my name and Friday last saying that the name given in the quarterly report for September for Standard 1 and 2 of the Day's School was Miss Roberts. Now I wish to notify you if such be the case that I am the one who was teacher of that class and made out that report although I was not permitted to sign my name. (Mary Demigan)

I am thrown out of work and must rely on the good will of my...
parents to support me.

Another thing I would like to know is how much salary does the Government allow to teachers of Standard Land?

Now I think that as recompense for the wrong done me I have sufficient grounds to claim my salary.

As a proof that I was teaching in Caughmanaga Mr. Brescan, your agent, visited my class on the Monday preceding my dismissal and judging from his outward appearance he seemed pleased with the class.

An immediate settlement of this affair would prove very beneficial to me.

With an apology,

Sincerely,

A true Canadian

Mary Durmegar

19-6 Azelair St

Montreal.
Ottawa, November 16, 1915.

Madam,

In reply to your letter of the 14th instant addressed to Mr. Benson of this Department I beg to say that the Boys' and Girls' Roman Catholic Schools on the Caughnawaga Reserve are under the control and management of the Sisters of St. Anne and the Department has no knowledge of the terms of your engagement with them. The arrangements made with the Sisters called for teachers holding professional qualifications, who were to be paid at the following rates, $500.00 for the principal, $400.00 for the first assistant and $300.00 for the second assistant. Any claim you have for salary should be made to them.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and secretary.

Langhamaga, Jan. 27, 1916.

Hon. L. C. Scott,
Ottawa.

Most esteemed Sir:

It seems to me that it is a duty incumbent upon me to inform you from time to time how our schools are progressing, and doubly so on account of the deep interest you express in the welfare of said schools. I am gratified today in being able to say that everything is going on well, and that we are steadily gaining the confidence of the people. The children are showing satisfactory progress notwithstanding their Indian mentality, and the drawback of not having had prior to our coming sufficient English in the Boys'
School. Some of the senior boys have expressed the wish to have good Mr. Scott's picture in their classroom. One of cabinet size would do. The senior class of girls would also appreciate the favor very much. However, if you consider my request too forward, please take no notice of it. I like the idea. It will teach the children respect and admiration for those who are doing so much for them.

Dear esteemed Mr. Scott—May I call your attention to the fact that it will be impossible for us to accept our present residence for another school year. It seems much too small for us, not speaking of the many inconveniences caused by the want of (many) of the indispensable requirements of a home. I therefore pray you send Mr. Scott to consider our case and have the Scott residence begun in early spring so that we may occupy it in September next.

Another thing which I must bring to your notice is that since January 1915
I have done the work of principal of the two schools here without remuneration for same. I have worked daily in the classes from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. When in preparation for concerts I have worked from 8 to 6 P.M. so as not to interfere with classes here. The schools are 34 mile apart, bad weather or bad walking were prevented me from reaching the schools at the appointed time. Mother M. Melanie and Superior General urge me to put this matter before you. I would not solicit a high salary but would accept with gratitude $500.00 per year, first payment dating from Sept. of this school year September last. Mother General can not accept to have the teachers' salary here to contribute to more as our expenses here are very high. We must get all our provisions etc. from Montreal, and with transport charges of same, everything costs us a great deal. I feel convinced that when you consider the hard work I have to accomplish here...
You will willingly extend to me the same privilege you so generously give to principals doing less arduous work. The task of principal is a difficult one and particularly so when the schools must be raised to a better standard.

I am presently engaged in forming a company of boys to instil a military and patriotic spirit in our young Squawkin boys.

Before concluding I must ask you Mr. Sir, to pardon this lengthy letter. I had many things to say, and I felt you would listen with indulgence to all.

With the highest consideration,

I have the honor to be, esteemed Sir,

Your humble and grateful servant,

H. M. Edward Principal,
Coughmore School.

INDIAN DAY SCHOOL REGULATIONS

1. The morning session shall be from 9 a.m. to 12 noon and the afternoon session from 1 p.m. to 5 p.m., with this arrangement subject to the approval of the Inspector of Indian Affairs. Any variation of this regulation must be approved by the Inspector's approval.

Indian Agent:

Dated: January 31st, 1927

Agents should see that full explanations are given by the teacher in the column for "Remarks", if the school was closed during the quarter for other than authorized holidays, and should also themselves make any necessary comments in that column.

INSTRUCTIONS TO TEACHERS

1. Fill up all the columns in this Return.
2. All the columns of the Return must be added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.
3. Number and date of holidays to be inserted in the column for remarks.
4. By the total number of school days in the quarter is meant the number of days in the quarter exclusive of Saturdays and Sundays. All authorized holidays will be allowed.
5. The standing of each pupil must be signified by inserting opposite his or her name the figure 1 in the column designating the particular day.
6. No names except those of pupils children are to be included in this return.
7. The correctly Returns must reach on the 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December respectively, and be immediately thereafter in each case transmitted to the local Indian Agent.
8. When adding to the number of pupils, the form of Return is not long enough to contain all the names, use another form, pagging it as No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns. Do not increase the length of the form by pasting another, or portion of one, thereto.
9. The average daily attendance during the quarter may be ascertained by dividing the total number of days attendance of all the pupils by the number of days school was open in the quarter.
10. Should the school be closed at any time during the quarter, the reason must be given in the column for remarks for such day or days.
11. The school must be opened and closed punctually at the hours approved of by the Department.
12. This form to be used for Day Schools only.
